1.verse: I am Isaiah, the son of Amoz. And this is the message that I was given about Judah and Jerusalem when Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah were the kings of Judah:

2.verse: A Guilty Nation - The LORD has said, “Listen, heaven and earth! The children I raised have turned against me.

3.verse: Oxen and donkeys know who owns and feeds them, but my people won’t ever learn.”

4.verse: Israel, you are a sinful nation loaded down with guilt. You are wicked and corrupt and have turned from the LORD, the holy God of Israel.

5.verse: Why be punished more? Why not give up your sin? Your head is badly bruised, and you are weak all over.

6.verse: From your head to your toes there isn’t a healthy spot. Bruises, cuts, and open sores go without care or oil to ease the pain.

7.verse: A Country in Ruins - Your country lies in ruins; your towns are in ashes. Foreigners and strangers take and destroy your land while you watch.

8.verse: Enemies surround Jerusalem, alone like a hut in a vineyard or in a cucumber field.

9.verse: Zion would have disappeared like Sodom and Gomorrah, if the LORD All-Powerful had not let a few of its people survive.

10.verse: Justice, Not Sacrifices - You are no better than the leaders and people of Sodom and Gomorrah! So listen to the LORD God:

11.verse: “Your sacrifices mean nothing to me. I am sick of your offerings of rams and choice cattle; I don’t like the blood of bulls or lambs or goats.

12.verse: “Who asked you to bring all this when you come to worship me? Stay out of my temple!

13.verse: Your sacrifices are worthless, and incense is disgusting. I can’t stand the evil you do on your New Moon Festivals or on your Sabbaths and other times of worship.

14.verse: I hate your New Moon Festivals and all others as well. They are a heavy burden I am tired of carrying.

15.verse: “No matter how much you pray, I won’t listen. You are too violent.

16.verse: Wash yourselves clean! I am disgusted with your filthy deeds. Stop doing wrong

17.verse: and learn to live right. See that justice is done. Defend widows and orphans and help those in need.”

18.verse: An Invitation from the LORD - I, the LORD, invite you to come and talk it over. Your sins are scarlet red, but they will be whiter than snow or wool.

19.verse: If you willingly obey me, the best crops in the land will be yours.

20.verse: But if you turn against me, your enemies will kill you. I, the LORD, have spoken.

21.verse: The LORD Condemns Jerusalem - Jerusalem, you are like an unfaithful wife. Once your judges were honest and your people lived right; now you are a city full of murderers.

22.verse: Your silver is fake, and your wine is watered down.

23.verse: Your leaders have rejected me to become friends of crooks; your rulers are looking for gifts and bribes. Widows and orphans never get a fair trial.

24.verse: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the mighty ruler of Israel, and I make you a promise: You are now my enemy, and I will show my anger by taking revenge on you.

25.verse: I will punish you terribly and burn away everything that makes you unfit to worship me.

26.verse: Jerusalem, I will choose judges and advisors like those you had before. Your new name will be “Justice and Faithfulness.”

27.verse: The LORD Will Save Jerusalem - Jerusalem, you will be saved by showing justice; Zion’s people who turn to me will be saved by doing right.

28.verse: But those rebellious sinners who turn against me, the LORD, will all disappear.

29.verse: You will be made ashamed of those groves of trees where you worshiped idols.

30.verse: You will be like a grove of trees dying in a drought.

31.verse: Your strongest leaders will be like dry wood set on fire by their idols. No one will be able to help, as they all go up in flames.

1.verse: Peace That Lasts Forever - This is the message that I was given about Judah and Jerusalem:

2.verse: In the future, the mountain with the LORD’s temple will be the highest of all. It will reach above the hills; every nation will rush to it.

3.verse: Many people will come and say, “Let’s go to the mountain of the LORD God of Jacob and worship in his temple.” The LORD will teach us his Law from Jerusalem, and we will obey him.

4.verse: He will settle arguments between nations. They will pound their swords and their spears into rakes and shovels; they will never make war or attack one another.

5.verse: People of Israel, let’s live by the light of the LORD.

6.verse: Following Sinful Customs - Our LORD, you have deserted your people, Israel, because they follow customs of nations from the east. They worship Philistine gods and are close friends of foreigners.

7.verse: They have endless treasures of silver and gold; they have countless horses and war chariots.

8.verse: Everywhere in the country they worship the idols they have made.

9.verse: And so, all of them will be ashamed and disgraced. Don’t help them!

10.verse: A Day of Judgment - Every one of you, go hide among the rocks and in the ground, because the LORD is fearsome, marvelous, and glorious.

11.verse: When the LORD comes, everyone who is proud will be made humble, and the LORD alone will be honored.

12.verse: The LORD All-Powerful has chosen a day when those who are proud and conceited will be put down.

13.verse: The tall and towering cedars of Lebanon will be destroyed. So will the oak trees of Bashan,

14.verse: all high mountains and hills,

15.verse: every strong fortress,

16.verse: all the seagoing ships, and every beautiful boat.

17.verse: When that day comes, everyone who is proud will be put down. Only the LORD will be honored.

18.verse: Idols will be gone for good.

19.verse: You had better hide in caves and holes— the LORD will be fearsome, marvelous, and glorious when he comes to terrify people on earth.

20.verse: On that day everyone will throw to the rats and bats their idols of silver and gold they made to worship.

21.verse: The LORD will be fearsome, marvelous, and glorious when he comes to terrify people on earth— they will hide in caves and in the hills.

22.verse: Stop trusting the power of humans. They are all going to die, so how can they help?

1.verse: Judgment on Jerusalem and Judah - The mighty LORD All-Powerful is going to take away from Jerusalem and Judah everything you need— your bread and water,

2.verse: soldiers and heroes, judges and prophets, leaders and army officers,

3.verse: officials and advisors, fortunetellers and others who tell the future.

4.verse: He will let children and babies become your rulers.

5.verse: You will each be cruel to friends and neighbors. Young people will insult their elders; no one will show respect to those who deserve it.

6.verse: Some of you will grab hold of a relative and say, “You still have a coat. Be our leader and rule this pile of ruins.”

7.verse: But the answer will be, “I can’t do you any good. Don’t make me your leader. There’s no food or clothing left in my house.”

8.verse: Jerusalem and Judah, you rebelled against your glorious LORD— your words and your actions, made you stumble and fall.

9.verse: The look on your faces shows that you are sinful as Sodom, and you don’t try to hide it. You are in for trouble, and you have brought it all on yourselves.

10.verse: The Wrong Kind of Leaders - Tell those who obey God, “You’re very fortunate— you will be rewarded for what you have done.”

11.verse: Tell those who disobey, “You’re in big trouble— what you did to others will come back to you.”

12.verse: Though you are God’s people, you are ruled and abused by women and children. You are confused by leaders who guide you down the wrong path.

13.verse: The LORD is ready to accuse and judge all nations.

14.verse: He will even judge you rulers and leaders of his own nation. You destroyed his vineyard and filled your houses by robbing the poor.

15.verse: The LORD All-Powerful says, “You have crushed my people and rubbed in the dirt the faces of the poor.”

16.verse: The Women of Jerusalem - The LORD says: The women of Jerusalem are proud and strut around, winking shamelessly. They wear anklets that jingle and call attention to the way they walk.

17.verse: But I, the LORD, will cover their heads with sores, and I will uncover their private parts.

18.verse: When that day comes, I will take away from those women all the fine jewelry they wear on their ankles, heads, necks, ears, arms, noses, fingers, and on their clothes. I will remove their veils, their belts, their perfume, their magic charms, their royal robes, and all their fancy dresses, hats, and purses.

I will remove their veils, their belts, their perfume, their magic charms, their royal robes, and all their fancy dresses, hats, and purses.

I will remove their veils, their belts, their perfume, their magic charms, their royal robes, and all their fancy dresses, hats, and purses.

I will remove their veils, their belts, their perfume, their magic charms, their royal robes, and all their fancy dresses, hats, and purses.

23.verse: When that day comes, I will take away from those women all the fine jewelry they wear on their ankles, heads, necks, ears, arms, noses, fingers, and on their clothes. I will remove their veils, their belts, their perfume, their magic charms, their royal robes, and all their fancy dresses, hats, and purses.

24.verse: In place of perfume, there will be a stink; in place of belts, there will be ropes; in place of fancy hairdos, they will have bald heads. Instead of expensive clothes, they will wear sackcloth; instead of beauty, they will have ugly scars.

25.verse: The fighting men of Jerusalem will be killed in battle.

26.verse: The city will mourn and sit in the dirt, emptied of its people.

1.verse: When this happens, seven women will grab the same man, and each of them will say, “I’ll buy my own food and clothes! Just marry me and take away my disgrace.”

2.verse: The LORD Will Bless His People Who Survive - The time is coming when the LORD will make his land fruitful and glorious again, and the people of Israel who survive will take great pride in what the land produces.

3.verse: Everyone who is left alive in Jerusalem will be called special,

4.verse: after the LORD sends a fiery judgment to clean the city and its people of their violent deeds.

5.verse: Then the LORD will cover the whole city and its meeting places with a thick cloud each day and with a flaming fire each night. God’s own glory will be like a huge tent that covers everything.

6.verse: It will provide shade from the heat of the sun and a place of shelter and protection from storms and rain.

1.verse: A Song about a Vineyard - The LORD said: I will sing a song about my friend’s vineyard that was on the side of a fertile hill.

2.verse: My friend dug the ground, removed the stones, and planted the best vines. He built a watchtower and dug a pit in rocky ground for pressing the grapes. He hoped they would be sweet, but bitter grapes were all it produced.

3.verse: Listen, people of Jerusalem and of Judah! You be the judge of me and my vineyard.

4.verse: What more could I have done for my vineyard? I hoped for sweet grapes, but bitter grapes were all that grew.

5.verse: Now I will let you know what I am going to do. I will cut down the hedge and tear down the wall. My vineyard will be trampled and left in ruins.

6.verse: It will turn into a desert, neither pruned nor hoed; it will be covered with thorns and briars. I will command the clouds not to send rain.

7.verse: I am the LORD All-Powerful! Israel is the vineyard, and Judah is the garden I tended with care. I had hoped for honesty and for justice, but dishonesty and cries for mercy were all I found.

8.verse: Isaiah Condemns Social Injustice - You are in for trouble! You take over house after house and field after field, until there is no room left for anyone else in all the land.

9.verse: But the LORD All-Powerful has made this promise to me: Those large and beautiful homes will be left empty, with no one to take care of them.

10.verse: Ten acres of grapevines will produce only six gallons of juice, and five bushels of seed will produce merely a half-bushel of grain.

11.verse: You are in for trouble! You get up early to start drinking, and you keep it up late into the night.

12.verse: At your drinking parties you have the music of stringed instruments, tambourines, and flutes. But you never even think about all the LORD has done,

13.verse: and so his people know nothing about him. That’s why many of you will be dragged off to foreign lands. Your leaders will starve to death, and everyone else will suffer from thirst.

14.verse: The world of the dead has opened its mouth wide and is eagerly waiting for the leaders of Jerusalem and for its noisy crowds, especially for those who take pride in that city.

15.verse: Its citizens have been put down, and its proud people have been brought to shame.

16.verse: But the holy LORD God All-Powerful is praised, because he has shown who he is by bringing justice.

17.verse: His people will be like sheep grazing in their own pasture, and they will take off what was left by others.

18.verse: You are in for trouble! The lies you tell are like ropes by which you drag along sin and evil.

19.verse: And you say, “Let the holy God of Israel hurry up and do what he has promised, so we can see it for ourselves.”

20.verse: You are headed for trouble! You say wrong is right, darkness is light, and bitter is sweet.

21.verse: You think you are clever and smart.

22.verse: And you are great at drinking and mixing drinks. But you are in for trouble.

23.verse: You accept bribes to let the guilty go free, and you cheat the innocent out of a fair trial.

24.verse: You will go up in flames like straw and hay! You have rejected the teaching of the holy LORD God All-Powerful of Israel. Now your roots will rot, and your blossoms will turn to dust.

25.verse: You are the LORD’s people, but you made him terribly angry, and he struck you with his mighty arm. Mountains shook, and dead bodies covered the streets like garbage. The LORD is still angry, and he is ready to strike you again.

26.verse: Foreign Nations Will Attack - The LORD has signaled for the foreign nations to come and attack you. He has already whistled, and they are coming as fast as they can.

27.verse: None of them are tired. They don’t sleep or get drowsy, and they run without stumbling. Their belts don’t come loose; their sandal straps don’t break.

28.verse: Their arrows are sharp, and their bows are ready. The hoofs of their horses are hard as flint; the wheels of their war chariots turn as fast as a whirlwind.

29.verse: They roar and growl like fierce young lions as they grab their victims and drag them off where no one can rescue them.

30.verse: On the day they attack, they will roar like the ocean. And across the land you will see nothing but darkness and trouble, because the light of day will be covered by thick clouds.

1.verse: A Vision of the LORD in the Temple - In the year that King Uzziah died, I had a vision of the LORD. He was on his throne high above, and his robe filled the temple.

2.verse: Flaming creatures with six wings each were flying over him. They covered their faces with two of their wings and their bodies with two more. They used the other two wings for flying,

3.verse: as they shouted, “Holy, holy, holy, LORD All-Powerful! The earth is filled with your glory.”

4.verse: As they shouted, the doorposts of the temple shook, and the temple was filled with smoke.

5.verse: Then I cried out, “I’m doomed! Everything I say is sinful, and so are the words of everyone around me. Yet I have seen the King, the LORD All-Powerful.”

6.verse: One of the flaming creatures flew over to me with a burning coal that it had taken from the altar with a pair of metal tongs.

7.verse: It touched my lips with the hot coal and said, “This has touched your lips. Your sins are forgiven, and you are no longer guilty.”

8.verse: After this, I heard the LORD ask, “Is there anyone I can send? Will someone go for us?” “I’ll go,” I answered. “Send me!”

9.verse: Then the LORD told me to go and speak this message to the people: “You will listen and listen, but never understand. You will look and look, but never see.” The LORD also said,

10.verse: “Make these people stubborn! Make them stop up their ears, cover their eyes, and fail to understand. Don’t let them turn to me and be healed.”

11.verse: Then I asked the LORD, “How long will this last?” The LORD answered: Until their towns are destroyed and their houses are deserted, until their fields are empty,

12.verse: and I have sent them far away, leaving their land in ruins.

13.verse: If only a tenth of the people are left, even they will be destroyed. But just as stumps remain after trees have been cut down, some of my chosen ones will be left.

1.verse: Isaiah Offers Hope to King Ahaz - Ahaz, the son of Jotham and the grandson of Uzziah, was king of Judah when King Rezin of Syria and King Pekah son of Remaliah of Israel went to attack Jerusalem. But they were not able to do what they had planned.

2.verse: When news reached the royal palace that Syria had joined forces with Israel, King Ahaz and everyone in Judah were so terrified that they shook like trees in a windstorm.

3.verse: Then the LORD said to me: Take your son Shearjashub and go see King Ahaz. You will find him on the road near the cloth makers' shops at the end of the canal that brings water from the upper pool.

4.verse: Tell Ahaz to stop worrying. There’s no need for him to be afraid of King Rezin and King Pekah. They are very angry, but they are nothing more than a dying fire. Ahaz doesn’t need to fear

5.verse: their evil threats

6.verse: to invade and defeat Judah and Jerusalem and to let the son of Tabeel be king in his place.

7.verse: I, the LORD, promise that this will never happen.

8.verse: Damascus is just the capital of Syria, and King Rezin rules only in Damascus. Samaria is just the capital of Israel, and King Pekah rules only in Samaria. But in less than sixty-five years, Israel will be destroyed. And if Ahaz and his officials don’t trust me, they will be defeated.

9.verse: Damascus is just the capital of Syria, and King Rezin rules only in Damascus. Samaria is just the capital of Israel, and King Pekah rules only in Samaria. But in less than sixty-five years, Israel will be destroyed. And if Ahaz and his officials don’t trust me, they will be defeated.

10.verse: A Son Named Immanuel - Once again the LORD God spoke to King Ahaz. This time he said,

11.verse: “Ask me for proof that my promise will come true. Ask for something to happen deep in the world of the dead or high in the heavens above.”

12.verse: “No, LORD,” Ahaz answered. “I won’t test you!”

13.verse: Then I said: Listen, every one of you in the royal family of David. You have already tried my patience. Now you are trying God’s patience by refusing to ask for proof.

14.verse: But the LORD will still give you proof. A virgin is pregnant; she will have a son and will name him Immanuel.

15.verse: Even before the boy is old enough to know how to choose between right and wrong, he will eat yogurt and honey, and the countries of the two kings you fear will be destroyed.

16.verse: Even before the boy is old enough to know how to choose between right and wrong, he will eat yogurt and honey, and the countries of the two kings you fear will be destroyed.

17.verse: But the LORD will make more trouble for your people and your kingdom than any of you have known since Israel broke away from Judah. He will even bring the king of Assyria to attack you.

18.verse: The Threat of an Invasion - When that time comes, the LORD will whistle, and armies will come from Egypt like flies and from Assyria like bees.

19.verse: They will settle everywhere—in the deep valleys and between the rocks, on every bush and all over the pastureland.

20.verse: The Lord will pay the king of Assyria to bring a razor from across the Euphrates River and shave your head and every hair on your body, including your beard.

21.verse: No one will have more than one young cow and two sheep,

22.verse: but those who do will have enough milk to make yogurt. In fact, everyone left in the land will eat yogurt and honey.

23.verse: Vineyards that had a thousand vines and were worth a thousand pieces of silver will turn into thorn patches.

24.verse: You will go there to hunt with your bow and arrows, because the whole country will be covered with thornbushes.

25.verse: The hills where you once planted crops will be overgrown with thorns and thistles. You will be afraid to go there, and your cattle, sheep, and goats will be turned loose on those hills.

1.verse: A Warning and a Hope - The LORD said, “Isaiah, get something to write on. Then write in big clear letters the name, MAHER-SHALAL-HASH-BAZ.

2.verse: I will have Uriah the priest and Zechariah son of Jeberechiah serve as witnesses to this.”

3.verse: Sometime later, my wife and I had a son, and the LORD said, “Name him Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz.

4.verse: Because before he can say ‘Mommy’ or ‘Daddy’, the king of Assyria will attack and take everything of value from Damascus and Samaria.”

5.verse: The LORD spoke to me again and said:

6.verse: These people have refused the gentle waters of Shiloah and have gladly gone over to the side of King Rezin and King Pekah.

7.verse: Now I will send the king of Assyria against them with his powerful army, which will attack like the mighty Euphrates River overflowing its banks.

8.verse: Enemy soldiers will cover Judah like a flood reaching up to your neck. But God is with us. He will spread his wings and protect our land.

9.verse: All of you foreign nations, go ahead and prepare for war, but you will be crushed.

10.verse: Get together and make plans, but you will fail because God is with us.

11.verse: The LORD took hold of me with his powerful hand and said: I’m warning you! Don’t act like these people.

12.verse: Don’t call something a rebellious plot, just because they do, and don’t be afraid of something, just because they are.

13.verse: I am the one you should fear and respect. I am the holy God, the LORD All-Powerful!

14.verse: Run to me for protection. I am a rock that will make both Judah and Israel stumble and break their bones. I am a trap that will catch the people of Jerusalem—they will be captured and dragged away.

15.verse: Run to me for protection. I am a rock that will make both Judah and Israel stumble and break their bones. I am a trap that will catch the people of Jerusalem—they will be captured and dragged away.

16.verse: Isaiah and His Followers - My message and my teachings are to be sealed and given to my followers.

17.verse: Meanwhile, I patiently trust the LORD, even though he is no longer pleased with Israel.

18.verse: My children and I are warning signs to Israel from the LORD All-Powerful, who lives on Mount Zion.

19.verse: Someone may say to you, “Go to the fortunetellers who make soft chirping sounds or ask the spirits of the dead. After all, a nation ought to be able to ask its own gods

20.verse: what it should do.” None of those who talk like that will live to see the light of day!

21.verse: They will go around in great pain and will become so hungry that they will angrily curse their king and their gods. And when they try to find help in heaven

22.verse: and on earth, they will find only trouble and darkness, terrible trouble and deepest darkness.

1.verse: But those who have suffered will no longer be in pain. The territories of Zebulun and Naphtali in Galilee were once hated. But this land of the Gentiles across the Jordan River and along the Mediterranean Sea will be greatly respected.

2.verse: War Is Over - Those who walked in the dark have seen a bright light. And it shines upon everyone who lives in the land of darkest shadows.

3.verse: Our LORD, you have made your nation stronger. Because of you, its people are glad and celebrate like workers at harvest time or like soldiers dividing up what they have taken.

4.verse: You have broken the power of those who abused and enslaved your people. You have rescued them just as you saved your people from Midian.

5.verse: The boots of marching warriors and the blood-stained uniforms have been fed to flames and eaten by fire.

6.verse: A Child Has Been Born - A child has been born for us. We have been given a son who will be our ruler. His names will be Wonderful Advisor and Mighty God, Eternal Father and Prince of Peace.

7.verse: His power will never end; peace will last forever. He will rule David’s kingdom and make it grow strong. He will always rule with honesty and justice. The LORD All-Powerful will make certain that all of this is done.

8.verse: God Will Punish Israel - The Lord had warned the people of Israel,

9.verse: and all of them knew it, including everyone in the capital city of Samaria. But they were proud and stubborn and said,

10.verse: “Houses of brick and sycamore have fallen to the ground, but we will build houses with stones and cedar.”

11.verse: The LORD made their enemies attack them.

12.verse: He sent the Arameans from the east and the Philistines from the west, and they swallowed up Israel. But even this did not stop him from being angry, so he kept on punishing them.

13.verse: The people of Israel still did not turn back to the LORD All-Powerful and worship him.

14.verse: In one day he cut off their head and tail, their leaves and branches.

15.verse: Their rulers and leaders were the head, and the lying prophets were the tail.

16.verse: They had led the nation down the wrong path, and the people were confused.

17.verse: The Lord was angry with his people and kept punishing them, because they had turned against him. They were evil and spoke foolishly. That’s why he did not have pity on their young people or on their widows and orphans.

18.verse: Evil had spread like a raging forest fire sending thornbushes up in smoke.

19.verse: The LORD All-Powerful was angry and used the people as fuel for a fire that scorched the land. They turned against each other

20.verse: like wild animals attacking and eating everyone around them, even their own relatives. But still they were not satisfied.

21.verse: The tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh turned against each other, then joined forces to attack Judah. But the LORD was still angry and ready to punish the nation even more.

1.verse: You people are in for trouble! You have made cruel and unfair laws

2.verse: that let you cheat the poor and needy and rob widows and orphans.

3.verse: But what will you do when you are fiercely attacked and punished by foreigners? Where will you run for help? Where will you hide your valuables?

4.verse: How will you escape being captured or killed? The Lord is still angry, and he isn’t through with you yet!

5.verse: The Lord’s Purpose and the King of Assyria - The Lord says: I am furious! And I will use the king of Assyria as a club

6.verse: to beat down you godless people. I am angry with you, and I will send him to attack you. He will take what he wants and walk on you like mud in the streets.

7.verse: He has even bigger plans in mind, because he wants to destroy many nations.

8.verse: The king of Assyria says: My army commanders are kings!

9.verse: They have already captured the cities of Calno, Carchemish, Hamath, Arpad, Samaria, and Damascus.

10.verse: The gods of Jerusalem and Samaria are weaker than the gods of those powerful nations. And I will destroy Jerusalem, together with its gods and idols, just as I did Samaria.

11.verse: The gods of Jerusalem and Samaria are weaker than the gods of those powerful nations. And I will destroy Jerusalem, together with its gods and idols, just as I did Samaria.

12.verse: The Lord will do what he has planned against Jerusalem and Mount Zion. Then he will punish the proud and boastful king of Assyria,

13.verse: who says: I did these things by my own power because I am smart and clever. I attacked kings like a wild bull, and I took the land and the treasures of their nations.

14.verse: I have conquered the whole world! And it was easier than taking eggs from an unguarded nest. No one even flapped a wing or made a peep.

15.verse: King of Assyria, can an ax or a saw overpower the one who uses it? Can a wooden pole lift whoever holds it?

16.verse: The mighty LORD All-Powerful will send a terrible disease to strike down your army, and you will burn with fever under your royal robes.

17.verse: The holy God, who is the light of Israel, will turn into a fire, and in one day you will go up in flames, just like a thornbush.

18.verse: The Lord will make your beautiful forests and fertile fields slowly rot.

19.verse: There will be so few trees that even a young child can count them.

20.verse: Only a Few Will Come Back - A time is coming when the survivors from Israel and Judah will completely depend on the holy LORD of Israel, instead of the nation that defeated them.

21.verse: There were as many people as there are grains of sand along the seashore, but only a few will survive to come back to Israel’s mighty God. This is because he has threatened to destroy their nation, just as they deserve.

22.verse: There were as many people as there are grains of sand along the seashore, but only a few will survive to come back to Israel’s mighty God. This is because he has threatened to destroy their nation, just as they deserve.

23.verse: The LORD All-Powerful has promised that everyone on this earth will be punished.

24.verse: Now the LORD God All-Powerful says to his people in Jerusalem: The Assyrians will beat you with sticks and abuse you, just as the Egyptians did. But don’t be afraid of them.

25.verse: Soon I will stop being angry with you, and I will punish them for their crimes.

26.verse: I will beat the Assyrians with a whip, as I did the people of Midian near the rock at Oreb. And I will show the same mighty power that I used when I made a path through the sea in Egypt.

27.verse: Then they will no longer rule your nation. All will go well for you, and your burden will be lifted.

28.verse: Enemy troops have reached the town of Aiath. They have gone through Migron, and they stored their supplies at Michmash,

29.verse: before crossing the valley and spending the night at Geba. The people of Ramah are terrified; everyone in Gibeah, the hometown of Saul, has run away.

30.verse: Loud crying can be heard in the towns of Gallim, Laishah, and sorrowful Anathoth.

31.verse: No one is left in Madmenah or Gebim.

32.verse: Today the enemy will camp at Nob and shake a threatening fist at Mount Zion in Jerusalem.

33.verse: But the LORD All-Powerful will use his fearsome might to bring down the tallest trees and chop off every branch.

34.verse: With an ax, the glorious Lord will destroy every tree in the forests of Lebanon.

1.verse: Peace at Last - Like a branch that sprouts from a stump, someone from David’s family will someday be king.

2.verse: The Spirit of the LORD will be with him to give him understanding, wisdom, and insight. He will be powerful, and he will know and honor the LORD.

3.verse: His greatest joy will be to obey the LORD. This king won’t judge by appearances or listen to rumors.

4.verse: The poor and the needy will be treated with fairness and with justice. His word will be law everywhere in the land, and criminals will be put to death.

5.verse: Honesty and fairness will be his royal robes.

6.verse: Leopards will lie down with young goats, and wolves will rest with lambs. Calves and lions will eat together and be cared for by little children.

7.verse: Cows and bears will share the same pasture; their young will rest side by side. Lions and oxen will both eat straw.

8.verse: Little children will play near snake holes. They will stick their hands into dens of poisonous snakes and never be hurt.

9.verse: Nothing harmful will take place on the LORD’s holy mountain. Just as water fills the sea, the land will be filled with people who know and honor the LORD.

10.verse: God’s People Will Come Back Home - The time is coming when one of David’s descendants will be the signal for the people of all nations to come together. They will follow his advice, and his own nation will become famous.

11.verse: When that day comes, the Lord will again reach out his mighty arm and bring home his people who have survived in Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Ethiopia, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, and the land along the coast.

12.verse: He will give a signal to the nations, and he will bring together the refugees from Judah and Israel, who have been scattered all over the earth.

13.verse: Israel will stop being jealous of Judah, and Judah will no longer be the enemy of Israel.

14.verse: Instead, they will get together and attack the Philistines in the west. Then they will defeat the Edomites, the Moabites, and the Ammonites in the east. They will rule those people and take from them whatever they want.

15.verse: The Lord will dry up the arm of the Red Sea near Egypt, and he will send a scorching wind to divide the Euphrates River into seven streams that anyone can step across.

16.verse: Then for his people who survive, there will be a good road from Assyria, just as there was a good road for their ancestors when they left Egypt.

1.verse: A Song of Praise - At that time you will say, “I thank you, LORD! You were angry with me, but you stopped being angry and gave me comfort.

2.verse: I trust you to save me, LORD God, and I won’t be afraid. My power and my strength come from you, and you have saved me.”

3.verse: With great joy, you people will get water from the well of victory.

4.verse: At that time you will say, “Our LORD, we are thankful, and we worship only you. We will tell the nations how glorious you are and what you have done.

5.verse: Because of your wonderful deeds we will sing your praises everywhere on earth.”

6.verse: Sing, people of Zion! Celebrate the greatness of the holy LORD of Israel. God is here to help you.

1.verse: Babylon Will Be Punished - This is the message that I was given about Babylon:

2.verse: From high on a barren hill give a signal, shout the orders, and point the way to enter the gates of Babylon’s proud rulers.

3.verse: The LORD has commanded his very best warriors and his proud heroes to show how angry he is.

4.verse: Listen to the noisy crowds on the mountains! Kingdoms and nations are joining forces. The LORD All-Powerful is bringing together an army for battle.

5.verse: From a distant land the LORD is coming fierce and furious— he brings his weapons to destroy the earth.

6.verse: Cry and weep! The day is coming when the mighty LORD will bring destruction.

7.verse: All people will be terrified. Hands will grow limp; courage will melt away.

8.verse: Everyone will tremble with pain like a woman giving birth; they will stare at each other with horror on their faces.

9.verse: There Will Be No Mercy - I, the LORD, will show no mercy or pity when that time comes. In my anger I will destroy the earth and every sinner who lives on it.

10.verse: Light will disappear from the stars in the sky; the dawning sun will turn dark, and the moon will lose its glow.

11.verse: I will punish this evil world and its people because of their sins. I will crush the horrible pride of those who are cruel.

12.verse: Survivors will be harder to find than the purest gold.

13.verse: I, the LORD All-Powerful, am terribly angry— I will make the sky tremble and the earth shake loose.

14.verse: Everyone will run to their homelands, just as hunted deer run, and sheep scatter when they have no shepherd.

15.verse: Those who are captured will be killed by a sword.

16.verse: They will see their children beaten against rocks, their homes robbed, and their wives abused.

17.verse: The Medes can’t be bought off with silver or gold, and I’m sending them to attack Babylonia.

18.verse: Their arrows will slaughter the young men; no pity will be shown to babies and children.

19.verse: The LORD Will Destroy Babylon - The city of Babylon is glorious and powerful, the pride of the nation. But it will be like the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah after I, the Lord, destroyed them.

20.verse: No one will live in Babylon. Even nomads won’t camp nearby, and shepherds won’t let their sheep rest there.

21.verse: Only desert creatures, hoot owls, and ostriches will live in its ruins, and goats will leap about.

22.verse: Hyenas and wolves will howl from Babylon’s fortresses and beautiful palaces. Its time is almost up!

1.verse: The LORD’s People Will Come Home - The LORD will have mercy on Israel and will let them be his chosen people once again. He will bring them back to their own land, and foreigners will join them as part of Israel.

2.verse: Other nations will lead them home, and Israel will make slaves of them in the land that belongs to the Lord. Israel will rule over those who once governed and mistreated them.

3.verse: Death to the King of Babylonia! - The LORD will set you free from your sorrow, suffering, and slavery.

4.verse: Then you will make fun of the King of Babylonia by singing this song: That cruel monster is done for! He won’t attack us again.

5.verse: The LORD has crushed the power of those evil kings,

6.verse: who were furious and never stopped abusing the people of other nations.

7.verse: Now all the world is at peace; its people are celebrating with joyful songs.

8.verse: King of Babylonia, even the cypress trees and the cedars of Lebanon celebrate and say, “Since you were put down, no one comes along to chop us down.”

9.verse: The world of the dead eagerly waits for you. With great excitement, the spirits of ancient rulers hear about your coming.

10.verse: Each one of them will say, “Now you are just as weak as any of us!

11.verse: Your pride and your music have ended here in the world of the dead. Worms are your blanket, maggots are your bed.”

12.verse: You, the bright morning star, have fallen from the sky! You brought down other nations; now you are brought down.

13.verse: You said to yourself, “I’ll climb to heaven and place my throne above the highest stars. I’ll sit there with the gods far away in the north.

14.verse: I’ll be above the clouds, just like God Most High.”

15.verse: But now you are deep in the world of the dead.

16.verse: Those who see you will stare and wonder, “Is this the man who made the world tremble and shook up kingdoms?

17.verse: Did he capture every city and make earth a desert? Is he the one who refused to let prisoners go home?”

18.verse: When kings die, they are buried in glorious tombs.

19.verse: But you will be left unburied, just another dead body lying underfoot like a broken branch. You will be one of many killed in battle and gone down to the deep rocky pit.

20.verse: You won’t be buried with kings; you ruined your country and murdered your people. You evil monster! We hope that your family will be forgotten forever.

21.verse: We will slaughter your sons to make them pay for the crimes of their ancestors. They won’t take over the world or build cities anywhere on this earth.

22.verse: The LORD All-Powerful has promised to attack Babylonia and destroy everyone there, so that none of them will ever be remembered again.

23.verse: The LORD will sweep out the people, and the land will become a swamp for wild animals.

24.verse: Assyria Will Be Punished - The LORD All-Powerful has made this promise: Everything I have planned will happen just as I said.

25.verse: I will wipe out every Assyrian in my country, and I will crush those on my mountains. I will free my people from slavery to the Assyrians.

26.verse: I have planned this for the whole world, and my mighty arm controls every nation.

27.verse: I, the LORD All-Powerful, have made these plans. No one can stop me now!

28.verse: The Philistines Will Be Punished - This message came from the LORD in the year King Ahaz died:

29.verse: Philistines, don’t be happy just because the rod that punished you is broken. That rod will become a poisonous snake, and then a flying fiery dragon.

30.verse: The poor and needy will find pastures for their sheep and will live in safety. But I will starve some of you, and others will be killed.

31.verse: Cry and weep in the gates of your towns, you Philistines! Smoke blows in from the north, and every soldier is ready.

32.verse: If a messenger comes from a distant nation, you must say: “The LORD built Zion. Even the poorest of his people will find safety there.”

1.verse: Moab Will Be Punished - This is a message about Moab: The towns of Ar and Kir were destroyed in a night. Moab is left in ruins!

2.verse: Everyone in Dibon has gone up to the temple and the shrines to cry and weep. All of Moab is crying. Heads and beards are shaved because of what happened at Nebo and Medeba.

3.verse: In the towns and at home, everyone wears sackcloth and cries loud and long.

4.verse: From Heshbon and Elealeh, weeping is heard in Jahaz; Moab’s warriors scream while trembling with fear.

5.verse: Pity Moab - I pity Moab! Its people are running to Zoar and to Eglath-Shelishiyah. They cry on their way up to the town of Luhith; on the road to Horonaim they tell of disasters.

6.verse: The streams of Nimrim and the grasslands have dried up. Every plant is parched.

7.verse: The people of Moab are leaving, crossing over Willow Creek, taking everything they own and have worked for.

8.verse: In the towns of Eglaim and of Beerelim and everywhere else in Moab mournful cries are heard.

9.verse: The streams near Dimon are flowing with blood. But the Lord will bring even worse trouble to Dimon, because all in Moab who escape will be attacked by lions.

1.verse: More Troubles for Moab - Send lambs as gifts to the ruler of the land. Send them across the desert from Sela to Mount Zion.

2.verse: The women of Moab crossing the Arnon River are like a flock of birds scattered from their nests.

3.verse: Moab’s messengers say to the people of Judah, “Be kind and help us! Shade us from the heat of the noonday sun. Hide our refugees! Don’t turn them away.

4.verse: Let our people live in your country and find safety here.” Moab, your cruel enemies will disappear; they will no longer attack and destroy your land.

5.verse: Then a kingdom of love will be set up, and someone from David’s family will rule with fairness. He will do what is right and quickly bring justice.

6.verse: Moab’s Pride Is Destroyed - We have heard of Moab’s pride. Its people strut and boast, but without reason.

7.verse: Tell everyone in Moab to mourn for their nation. Tell them to cry and weep for those fancy raisins of Kir-Hareseth.

8.verse: Vineyards near Heshbon and Sibmah have turned brown. The rulers of nations used to get drunk on wine from those vineyards that spread to Jazer, then across the desert and beyond the sea.

9.verse: Now I mourn like Jazer for the vineyards of Sibmah. I shed tears for Heshbon and for Elealeh. There will be no more harvest celebrations

10.verse: or joyful and happy times, while bringing in the crops. Singing and shouting are gone from the vineyards. There are no joyful shouts where grapes were pressed. God has silenced them all.

11.verse: Deep in my heart I hurt for Moab and Kir-Heres.

12.verse: It’s useless for Moab’s people to wear themselves out by going to their altars to worship and pray.

13.verse: The LORD has already said all of this about Moab.

14.verse: Now he says, “The contract of a hired worker is good for three years, but Moab’s glory and greatness won’t last any longer than that. Only a few of its people will survive, and they will be left helpless.”

1.verse: Damascus Will Be Punished - This is a message about Damascus: Damascus is doomed! It will end up in ruins.

2.verse: The villages around Aroer will be deserted, with only sheep living there and no one to bother them.

3.verse: Israel will lose its fortresses. The kingdom of Damascus will be destroyed; its survivors will suffer the same fate as Israel. The LORD All-Powerful has promised this.

4.verse: Sin and Suffering - When that time comes, the glorious nation of Israel will be brought down; its prosperous people will be skin and bones.

5.verse: Israel will be like wheat fields in Rephaim Valley picked clean of grain.

6.verse: It will be like an olive tree beaten with a stick, leaving two or three olives or maybe four or five on the highest or most fruitful branches. The LORD God of Israel has promised this.

7.verse: At that time the people will turn and trust their Creator, the holy God of Israel.

8.verse: They have built altars and places for burning incense to their goddess Asherah, and they have set up sacred poles for her. But they will stop worshiping at these places.

9.verse: Israel captured powerful cities and chased out the people who lived there. But these cities will lie in ruins, covered over with weeds and underbrush.

10.verse: Israel, you have forgotten the God who saves you, the one who is the mighty rock where you find protection. You plant the finest flowers to honor a foreign god.

11.verse: The plants may sprout and blossom that very same morning, but it will do you no good, because you will suffer endless agony.

12.verse: God Defends His People - The nations are a noisy, thunderous sea.

13.verse: But even if they roar like a fearsome flood, God will give the command to turn them back. They will be like dust, or like a tumbleweed blowing across the hills in a windstorm.

14.verse: In the evening their attack is fierce, but by morning they are destroyed. This is what happens to those who raid and rob us.

1.verse: Ethiopia Will Be Punished - Downstream from Ethiopia lies the country of Egypt, swarming with insects.

2.verse: Egypt sends messengers up the Nile River on ships made of reeds. Send them fast to Ethiopia, whose people are tall and have smooth skin. Their land is divided by rivers; they are strong and brutal, feared all over the world.

3.verse: Everyone on this earth, listen with care! A signal will be given on the mountains, and you will hear a trumpet.

4.verse: The LORD said to me, “I will calmly look down from my home above— as calmly as the sun at noon or clouds in the heat of harvest season.”

5.verse: Before the blossoms can turn into grapes, God will cut off the sprouts and hack off the branches.

6.verse: Ethiopians will be food for mountain buzzards during the summer and for wild animals during the winter.

7.verse: Those Ethiopians are tall and their skin is smooth. They are feared all over the world, because they are strong and brutal. But at that time they will come from their land divided by rivers, and they will bring gifts to the LORD All-Powerful, who is worshiped on Mount Zion.

1.verse: Egypt Will Be Punished - This is a message about Egypt: The LORD comes to Egypt, riding swiftly on a cloud. The people are weak from fear. Their idols tremble as he approaches and says,

2.verse: “I will punish Egypt with civil war— neighbors, cities, and kingdoms will fight each other.

3.verse: “Egypt will be discouraged when I confuse their plans. They will try to get advice from their idols, from the spirits of the dead, and from fortunetellers.

4.verse: I will put the Egyptians under the power of a cruel, heartless king. I, the LORD All-Powerful, have promised this.”

5.verse: Trouble along the Nile - The Nile River will dry up and become parched land.

6.verse: Its streams will stink, Egypt will have no water, and the reeds and tall grass will dry up.

7.verse: Fields along the Nile will be completely barren; every plant will disappear.

8.verse: Those who fish in the Nile will be discouraged and mourn.

9.verse: None of the cloth makers will know what to do, and they will turn pale.

10.verse: Weavers will be confused; paid workers will cry and mourn.

11.verse: Egypt’s Helpless Leaders - The king’s officials in Zoan are foolish themselves and give stupid advice. How can they say to him, “We are very wise, and our families go back to kings of long ago?”

12.verse: Where are those wise men now? If they can, let them say what the LORD All-Powerful intends for Egypt.

13.verse: The royal officials in Zoan and in Memphis are foolish and deceived. The leaders in every state have given bad advice to the nation.

14.verse: The LORD has confused Egypt; its leaders have made it stagger and vomit like a drunkard.

15.verse: No one in Egypt can do a thing, no matter who they are.

16.verse: When the LORD All-Powerful punishes Egypt with his mighty arm, the Egyptians will become terribly weak and will tremble with fear.

17.verse: They will be so terrified of Judah that they will be frightened by the very mention of its name. This will happen because of what the LORD All-Powerful is planning against Egypt.

18.verse: The LORD Will Bless Egypt, Assyria, and Israel - The time is coming when Hebrew will be spoken in five Egyptian cities, and their people will become followers of the LORD. One of these cities will be called City of the Sun.

19.verse: In the heart of Egypt an altar will be set up for the LORD; at its border a shrine will be built to honor him.

20.verse: These will remind the Egyptians that the LORD All-Powerful is with them. And when they are in trouble and ask for help, he will send someone to rescue them from their enemies.

21.verse: The LORD will show the Egyptians who he is, and they will know and worship the LORD. They will bring him sacrifices and offerings, and they will keep their promises to him.

22.verse: After the LORD has punished Egypt, the people will turn to him. Then he will answer their prayers, and the Egyptians will be healed.

23.verse: At that time a good road will run from Egypt to Assyria. The Egyptians and the Assyrians will travel back and forth from Egypt to Assyria, and they will worship together.

24.verse: Israel will join with these two countries. They will be a blessing to everyone on earth,

25.verse: then the LORD All-Powerful will bless them by saying, “The Egyptians are my people. I created the Assyrians and chose the Israelites.”

1.verse: Isaiah Acts Out the Defeat of Egypt and Ethiopia - King Sargon of Assyria gave orders for his army commander to capture the city of Ashdod.

2.verse: About this same time the LORD had told me, “Isaiah, take off everything, including your sandals!” I did this and went around naked and barefoot

3.verse: for three years. Then the LORD said: What Isaiah has done is a warning to Egypt and Ethiopia.

4.verse: Everyone in these two countries will be led away naked and barefoot by the king of Assyria. Young or old, they will be taken prisoner, and Egypt will be disgraced.

5.verse: They will be confused and frustrated, because they depended on Ethiopia and bragged about Egypt.

6.verse: When this happens, the people who live along the coast will say, “Look what happened to them! We ran to them for safety, hoping they would protect us from the king of Assyria. But now, there is no escape for us.”

1.verse: The Fall of Babylonia - This is a message about a desert beside the sea: Enemies from a hostile nation attack like a whirlwind from the Southern Desert.

2.verse: What a horrible vision was shown to me— a vision of betrayal and destruction. Tell Elam and Media to surround and attack the Babylonians. The LORD has sworn to end the suffering they caused.

3.verse: I’m in terrible pain like a woman giving birth. I’m shocked and hurt so much that I can’t hear or see.

4.verse: My head spins; I’m horrified! Early evening, my favorite time, has become a nightmare.

5.verse: In Babylon the high officials were having a feast. They were eating and drinking, when someone shouted, “Officers, take your places! Grab your shields.”

6.verse: The LORD said to me, “Send guards to find out what’s going on.

7.verse: When they see cavalry troops and columns of soldiers on donkeys and camels, tell them to be ready!”

8.verse: Then a guard said, “I have stood day and night on this watchtower, Lord.

9.verse: Now I see column after column of cavalry troops.” Right away someone shouted, “Babylon has fallen! Every idol in the city lies broken on the ground.”

10.verse: Then I said, “My people, you have suffered terribly, but I have a message for you from the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel.”

11.verse: How Much Longer? - This is a message about Dumah: From the country of Seir, someone shouts to me, “Guard, how much longer before daylight?”

12.verse: From my guard post, I answered, “Morning will soon be here, but night will return. If you want to know more, come back later.”

13.verse: This is a message for Arabs who live in the barren desert in the region of Dedan: You must order your caravans

14.verse: to bring water for those who are thirsty. You people of Tema must bring food for the hungry refugees.

15.verse: They are worn out and weary from being chased by enemies with swords and arrows.

16.verse: The Lord said to me: A year from now the glory of the people of Kedar will all come to an end, just as a worker’s contract ends after a year.

17.verse: Only a few of their warriors will be left with bows and arrows. This is a promise that I, the LORD God of Israel, have made.

1.verse: Trouble in Vision Valley - This is a message about Vision Valley: Why are you celebrating on the flat roofs of your houses?

2.verse: Your city is filled with noisy shouts. Those who lie drunk in your streets were not killed in battle.

3.verse: Your leaders ran away, but they were captured without a fight. No matter how far they ran, they were found and caught.

4.verse: Then I said, “Leave me alone! Let me cry bitter tears. My people have been destroyed, so don’t try to comfort me.”

5.verse: The LORD All-Powerful had chosen a time for noisy shouts and confusion to fill Vision Valley, and for everyone to beg the mountains for help.

6.verse: The people of Elam and Kir attacked with chariots and carried shields.

7.verse: Your most beautiful valleys were covered with chariots; your cities were surrounded by cavalry troops.

8.verse: Judah was left defenseless. At that time you trusted in the weapons you had stored in Forest Palace.

9.verse: You saw the holes in the outer wall of Jerusalem, and you brought water from the lower pool.

10.verse: You counted the houses in Jerusalem and tore down some of them, so you could get stones to repair the city wall.

11.verse: Then you built a large tank between the walls to store the water. But you refused to trust the God who planned this long ago and made it happen.

12.verse: A Time To Weep - When all of this happened, the LORD All-Powerful told you to weep and mourn, to shave your heads, and wear sackcloth.

13.verse: But instead, you celebrated by feasting on beef and lamb and by drinking wine, because you said, “Let’s eat and drink! Tomorrow we may die.”

14.verse: The LORD All-Powerful has spoken to me this solemn promise: “I won’t forgive them for this, not as long as they live.”

15.verse: Selfish Officials Are Doomed - The LORD All-Powerful is sending you with this message for Shebna, the prime minister:

16.verse: Shebna, what gives you the right to have a tomb carved out of rock in this burial place of royalty? None of your relatives are buried here.

17.verse: You may be powerful, but the LORD is about to snatch you up and throw you away.

18.verse: He will roll you into a ball and throw you into a wide open country, where you will die and your chariots will be destroyed. You’re a disgrace to those you serve.

19.verse: The LORD is going to take away your job!

20.verse: He will give your official robes and your authority to his servant Eliakim son of Hilkiah. Eliakim will be like a father to the people of Jerusalem and to the royal family of Judah.

21.verse: He will give your official robes and your authority to his servant Eliakim son of Hilkiah. Eliakim will be like a father to the people of Jerusalem and to the royal family of Judah.

22.verse: The LORD will put him in charge of the key that belongs to King David’s family. No one will be able to unlock what he locks, and no one will be able to lock what he unlocks.

23.verse: The LORD will make him as firm in his position as a tent peg hammered in the ground, and Eliakim will bring honor to his family.

24.verse: His children and relatives will be supported by him, like pans hanging from a peg on the wall.

25.verse: That peg is fastened firmly now, but someday it will be shaken loose and fall down. Then everything that was hanging on it will be destroyed. This is what the LORD All-Powerful has promised.

1.verse: The City of Tyre Will Be Punished - This is a message from distant islands about the city of Tyre: Cry, you seagoing ships! Tyre and its houses lie in ruins.

2.verse: Mourn in silence, you shop owners of Sidon, you people on the coast. Your sailors crossed oceans, making your city rich.

3.verse: Your merchants sailed the seas, making you wealthy by trading with nation after nation. They brought back grain that grew along the Nile.

4.verse: Sidon, you are a mighty fortress built along the sea. But you will be disgraced like a married woman who never had children.

5.verse: When Egypt hears about Tyre, it will tremble.

6.verse: All of you along the coast had better cry and sail far across the ocean.

7.verse: Can this be the happy city that has stood for centuries? Its people have spread to distant lands;

8.verse: its merchants were kings honored all over the world. Who planned to destroy Tyre?

9.verse: The LORD All-Powerful planned it to bring shame and disgrace to those who are honored by everyone on earth.

10.verse: People of Tyre, your harbor is destroyed! You will have to become farmers just like the Egyptians.

11.verse: Tyre Will Be Forgotten - The LORD’s hand has reached across the sea, upsetting the nations. He has given a command to destroy fortresses in the land of Canaan.

12.verse: The LORD has said to the people of Sidon, “Your celebrating is over— you are crushed. Even if you escape to Cyprus, you won’t find peace.”

13.verse: Look what the Assyrians have done to Babylonia! They have attacked, destroying every palace in the land. Now wild animals live among the ruins.

14.verse: Not a fortress will be left standing, so tell all the seagoing ships to mourn.

15.verse: The city of Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, which is the lifetime of a king. Then Tyre will be like that evil woman in the song:

16.verse: You’re gone and forgotten, you evil woman! So strut through the town, singing and playing your favorite tune to be remembered again.

17.verse: At the end of those seventy years, the LORD will let Tyre get back into business. The city will be like a woman who sells her body to everyone of every nation on earth,

18.verse: but none of what is earned will be kept in the city. That money will belong to the LORD, and it will be used to buy more than enough food and good clothes for those who worship the LORD.

1.verse: The Earth Will Be Punished - The LORD is going to twist the earth out of shape and turn it into a desert. Everyone will be scattered,

2.verse: including ordinary people and priests, slaves and slave owners, buyers and sellers, lenders and borrowers, the rich and the poor.

3.verse: The earth will be stripped bare and left that way. This is what the LORD has promised.

4.verse: The earth wilts away; its mighty leaders melt to nothing.

5.verse: The earth is polluted because its people disobeyed the laws of God, breaking their agreement that was to last forever.

6.verse: The earth is under a curse; its people are dying out because of their sins.

7.verse: Grapevines have dried up: wine is almost gone— mournful sounds are heard instead of joyful shouts.

8.verse: No one plays tambourines or stringed instruments; all noisy celebrating has come to an end.

9.verse: They no longer sing as they drink their wine, and it tastes sour.

10.verse: Towns are crushed and in chaos; houses are locked tight.

11.verse: Happy times have disappeared from the earth, and people shout in the streets, “We’re out of wine!”

12.verse: Cities are destroyed; their gates are torn down.

13.verse: Nations will be stripped bare, like olive trees or vineyards after the harvest season.

14.verse: Praise the God of Justice - People in the west shout; they joyfully praise the majesty of the LORD.

15.verse: And so, everyone in the east and those on the islands should praise the LORD, the God of Israel.

16.verse: From all over the world songs of praise are heard for the God of justice. But I feel awful, terribly miserable. Can anyone be trusted? So many are treacherous!

17.verse: There’s No Escape - Terror, traps, and pits are waiting for everyone.

18.verse: If you are terrified and run, you will fall into a pit; if you crawl out of the pit, you will get caught in a trap. The sky has split apart like a window thrown open. The foundations of the earth have been shaken;

19.verse: the earth is shattered, ripped to pieces.

20.verse: It staggers and shakes like a drunkard or a hut in a windstorm. It is burdened down with sin; the earth will fall, never again to get up.

21.verse: On that day the LORD will punish the powers in the heavens and the kings of the earth.

22.verse: He will put them in a pit and keep them prisoner. Then later on, he will punish them.

23.verse: The moon and sun will both be embarrassed and ashamed. The LORD All-Powerful will rule on Mount Zion in Jerusalem, where he will show its rulers his wonderful glory.

1.verse: A Prayer of Thanks to God - You, LORD, are my God! I will praise you for doing the wonderful things you had planned and promised since ancient times.

2.verse: You have destroyed the fortress of our enemies, leaving their city in ruins. Nothing in that foreign city will ever be rebuilt.

3.verse: Now strong and cruel nations will fear and honor you.

4.verse: You have been a place of safety for the poor and needy in times of trouble. Brutal enemies pounded us like a heavy rain or the heat of the sun at noon, but you were our shelter.

5.verse: Those wild foreigners struck like scorching desert heat. But you were like a cloud, protecting us from the sun. You kept our enemies from singing songs of victory.

6.verse: The LORD Has Saved Us - On this mountain the LORD All-Powerful will prepare for all nations a feast of the finest foods. Choice wines and the best meats will be served.

7.verse: Here the LORD will strip away the burial clothes that cover the nations.

8.verse: The LORD All-Powerful will destroy the power of death and wipe away all tears. No longer will his people be insulted everywhere. The LORD has spoken!

9.verse: At that time, people will say, “The LORD has saved us! Let’s celebrate. We waited and hoped— now our God is here.”

10.verse: The powerful arm of the LORD will protect this mountain. The Moabites will be put down and trampled on like straw in a pit of manure.

11.verse: They will struggle to get out, but God will humiliate them no matter how hard they try.

12.verse: The walls of their fortresses will be knocked down and scattered in the dirt.

1.verse: A Song of Victory - The time is coming when the people of Judah will sing this song: “Our city is protected. The LORD is our fortress, and he gives us victory.

2.verse: Open the city gates for a law-abiding nation that is faithful to God.

3.verse: The LORD gives perfect peace to those whose faith is firm.

4.verse: So always trust the LORD because he is forever our mighty rock.

5.verse: God has put down our enemies in their mountain city and rubbed it in the dirt.

6.verse: Now the poor and abused stomp all over that city.”

7.verse: The LORD Can Be Trusted - Our LORD, you always do right, and you make the path smooth for those who obey you.

8.verse: You are the one we trust to bring about justice; above all else we want your name to be honored.

9.verse: Throughout the night, my heart searches for you, because your decisions show everyone on this earth how to live right.

10.verse: Even when the wicked are treated with mercy in this land of justice, they do wrong and are blind to your glory, our LORD.

11.verse: Your hand is raised and ready to punish them, but they don’t see it. Put them to shame! Show how much you care for us and throw them into the fire intended for your enemies.

12.verse: You will give us peace, LORD, because everything we have done was by your power.

13.verse: Others have ruled over us besides you, our LORD God, but we obey only you.

14.verse: Those enemies are now dead and can never live again. You have punished them— they are destroyed, completely forgotten.

15.verse: Our nation has grown because of you, our LORD. We have more land than before, and you are honored.

16.verse: The LORD Gives Life to the Dead - When you punished our people, they turned and prayed to you, our LORD.

17.verse: Because of what you did to us, we suffered like a woman about to give birth.

18.verse: But instead of having a child, our terrible pain produced only wind. We have won no victories, and we have no descendants to take over the earth.

19.verse: Your people will rise to life! Tell them to leave their graves and celebrate with shouts. You refresh the earth like morning dew; you give life to the dead.

20.verse: Go inside and lock the doors, my people. Hide there for a little while, until the LORD is no longer angry.

21.verse: The Earth and the Sea Will Be Punished - The LORD will come out to punish everyone on earth for their sins. And when he does, those who did violent crimes will be known and punished.

1.verse: On that day, Leviathan, the sea monster, will squirm and try to escape, but the LORD will kill him with a cruel, sharp sword.

2.verse: Protection and Forgiveness - The LORD said: At that time you must sing about a fruitful vineyard.

3.verse: I, the LORD, will protect it and always keep it watered. I will guard it day and night to keep it from harm.

4.verse: I am no longer angry. But if it produces thorns, I will go to war against it and burn it to the ground.

5.verse: Yet if the vineyard depends on me for protection, it will become my friend and be at peace with me.

6.verse: Someday Israel will take root like a vine. It will blossom and bear fruit that covers the earth.

7.verse: I, the LORD, didn’t punish and kill the people of Israel as fiercely as I punished and killed their enemies.

8.verse: I carefully measured out Israel’s punishment and sent the scorching heat to chase them far away.

9.verse: There’s only one way that Israel’s sin and guilt can be completely forgiven: They must crush the stones of every pagan altar and place of worship.

10.verse: The LORD Will Bring His People Together - Fortress cities are left like a desert where no one lives. Cattle walk through the ruins, stripping the trees bare.

11.verse: When broken branches fall to the ground, women pick them up to feed the fire. But these people are so stupid that the God who created them will show them no mercy.

12.verse: The time is coming when the LORD will shake the land between the Euphrates River and the border of Egypt, and one by one he will bring all of his people together.

13.verse: A loud trumpet will be heard. Then the people of Israel who were dragged away to Assyria and Egypt will return to worship the LORD on his holy mountain in Jerusalem.

1.verse: Samaria Will Be Punished - The city of Samaria above a fertile valley is in for trouble! Its leaders are drunkards, who stuff themselves with food and wine. But they will be like flowers that dry up and wilt.

2.verse: Only the Lord is strong and powerful! His mighty hand will strike them down with the force of a hailstorm or a mighty whirlwind or an overwhelming flood.

3.verse: Every drunkard in Ephraim takes pride in Samaria, but it will be crushed.

4.verse: Samaria above a fertile valley will quickly lose its glory. It will be gobbled down like the first ripe fig at harvest season.

5.verse: When this time comes, the LORD All-Powerful will be a glorious crown for his people who survive.

6.verse: He will see that justice rules and that his people are able to defend their cities.

7.verse: Corrupt Leaders Will Be Punished - Priests and prophets stumble because they are drunk. Their minds are too confused to receive God’s messages or give honest decisions.

8.verse: Their tables are covered, completely covered, with their stinking vomit.

9.verse: You drunken leaders are like babies! How can you possibly understand or teach the LORD’s message?

10.verse: You don’t even listen— all you hear is senseless sound after senseless sound.

11.verse: So, the Lord will speak to his people in strange sounds and foreign languages.

12.verse: He promised you perfect peace and rest, but you refused to listen.

13.verse: Now his message to you will be senseless sound after senseless sound. Then you will fall backwards, injured and trapped.

14.verse: False Security Is Fatal - You rulers of Jerusalem do nothing but sneer; now you must listen to what the LORD says.

15.verse: Do you think you have an agreement with death and the world of the dead? Why do you trust in your lies to keep you safe from danger and the mighty flood?

16.verse: And so the LORD says, “I’m laying a firm foundation for the city of Zion. It’s a valuable cornerstone proven to be trustworthy; no one who trusts it will ever be disappointed.

17.verse: Justice and fairness will be the measuring lines that help me build.” Hailstones and floods will destroy and wash away your shelter of lies.

18.verse: Your agreement with death and the world of the dead will be broken. Then angry, roaring waves will sweep over you.

19.verse: Morning, noon, and night an overwhelming flood will wash you away. The terrible things that happen will teach you this lesson:

20.verse: Your bed is too short, your blanket too skimpy.

21.verse: The LORD will fiercely attack as he did at Mount Perazim and in Gibeon Valley. But this time the LORD will do something surprising, not what you expect.

22.verse: So you had better stop sneering or you will be in worse shape than ever before. I heard the LORD All-Powerful threaten the whole country with destruction.

23.verse: All Wisdom Comes from the LORD - Pay close attention to what I am saying.

24.verse: Farmers don’t just plow and break up the ground.

25.verse: When a field is ready, they scatter the seeds of dill and cumin; they plant the seeds of wheat and barley in the proper places.

26.verse: They learn this from their God.

27.verse: After dill and cumin have been harvested, the stalks are pounded, not run over with a wagon.

28.verse: Wheat and barley are pounded, but not beaten to pulp; they are run over with a wagon, but not ground to dust.

29.verse: This wonderful knowledge comes from the LORD All-Powerful, who has such great wisdom.

1.verse: Jerusalem Will Suffer - The LORD said: Jerusalem, city of David, the place of my altar, you are in for trouble! Celebrate your festivals year after year.

2.verse: I will still make you suffer, and your people will cry when I make an altar of you.

3.verse: I will surround you and prepare to attack from all sides.

4.verse: From deep in the earth, you will call out for help with only a faint whisper.

5.verse: Then your cruel enemies will suddenly be swept away like dust in a windstorm.

6.verse: I, the LORD All-Powerful, will come to your rescue with a thundering earthquake and a fiery whirlwind.

7.verse: Every brutal nation that attacks Jerusalem and makes it suffer will disappear like a dream when night is over.

8.verse: Those nations that attack Mount Zion will suffer from hunger and thirst. They will dream of food and drink but wake up weary and hungry and thirsty as ever.

9.verse: Prophets Who Fool Themselves - Be shocked and stunned, you prophets! Refuse to see. Get drunk and stagger, but not from wine.

10.verse: The LORD has made you drowsy; he put you into a deep sleep and covered your head.

11.verse: Now his message is like a sealed letter to you. Some of you say, “We can’t read it, because it’s sealed.”

12.verse: Others say, “We can’t read it, because we don’t know how to read.”

13.verse: The Lord has said: “These people praise me with their words, but they never really think about me. They worship me by repeating rules made up by humans.

14.verse: So once again I will do things that shock and amaze them, and I will destroy the wisdom of those who claim to know and understand.”

15.verse: You are in for trouble, if you try to hide your plans from the LORD! Or if you think what you do in the dark can’t be seen.

16.verse: You have it all backwards. A clay dish doesn’t say to the potter, “You didn’t make me. You don’t even know how.”

17.verse: Hope for the Future - Soon the forest of Lebanon will become a field with crops, thick as a forest.

18.verse: The deaf will be able to hear whatever is read to them; the blind will be freed from a life of darkness.

19.verse: The poor and the needy will celebrate and shout because of the LORD, the holy God of Israel.

20.verse: All who are cruel and arrogant will be gone forever. Those who live by crime will disappear,

21.verse: together with everyone who tells lies in court and keeps innocent people from getting a fair trial.

22.verse: The LORD who rescued Abraham has this to say about Jacob’s descendants: “They will no longer be ashamed and disgraced.

23.verse: When they see how great I have made their nation, they will praise and honor me, the holy God of Israel.

24.verse: Everyone who is confused will understand, and all who have complained will obey my teaching.”

1.verse: Don’t Expect Help from Egypt - This is the LORD’s message for his rebellious people: “You follow your own plans instead of mine; you make treaties without asking me, and you keep on sinning.

2.verse: You trust Egypt for protection. So you refuse my advice and send messengers to Egypt to beg their king for help.

3.verse: You will be disappointed, completely disgraced for trusting Egypt.

4.verse: The king’s power reaches from the city of Zoan as far south as Hanes.

5.verse: But Egypt can’t protect you, and to trust that nation is useless and foolish.”

6.verse: This is a message about the animals of the Southern Desert: You people carry treasures on donkeys and camels. You travel to a feeble nation through a troublesome desert filled with lions and flying fiery dragons.

7.verse: Egypt can’t help you! That’s why I call that nation a helpless monster.”

8.verse: Israel Refuses To Listen - The LORD told me to write down his message for his people, so that it would be there forever.

9.verse: They have turned against the LORD and can’t be trusted. They have refused his teaching

10.verse: and have said to his messengers and prophets: Don’t tell us what God has shown you and don’t preach the truth. Just say what we want to hear, even if it’s false.

11.verse: Stop telling us what God has said! We don’t want to hear any more about the holy God of Israel.

12.verse: Now this is the answer of the holy God of Israel: “You rejected my message, and you trust in violence and lies.

13.verse: This sin is like a crack that makes a high wall quickly crumble

14.verse: and shatter like a crushed bowl. There’s not a piece left big enough to carry hot coals or to dip out water.”

15.verse: Trust the LORD - The holy LORD God of Israel had told all of you, “I will keep you safe if you turn back to me and calm down. I will make you strong if you quietly trust me.” Then you stubbornly

16.verse: said, “No! We will safely escape on speedy horses.” But those who chase you will be even faster.

17.verse: As few as five of them, or even one, will be enough to chase a thousand of you. Finally, all that will be left will be a few survivors as lonely as a flag pole on a barren hill.

18.verse: The LORD Will Show Mercy - The LORD God is waiting to show how kind he is and to have pity on you. The LORD always does right; he blesses those who trust him.

19.verse: People of Jerusalem, you don’t need to cry anymore. The Lord is kind, and as soon as he hears your cries for help, he will come.

20.verse: The Lord has given you trouble and sorrow as your food and drink. But now you will again see the Lord, your teacher, and he will guide you.

21.verse: Whether you turn to the right or to the left, you will hear a voice saying, “This is the road! Now follow it.”

22.verse: Then you will treat your idols of silver and gold like garbage; you will throw them away like filthy rags.

23.verse: The Lord will send rain to water the seeds you have planted—your fields will produce more crops than you need, and your cattle will graze in open pastures.

24.verse: Even the oxen and donkeys that plow your fields will be fed the finest grain.

25.verse: On that day people will be slaughtered and towers destroyed, but streams of water will flow from high hills and towering mountains.

26.verse: Then the LORD will bandage his people’s injuries and heal the wounds he has caused. The moon will shine as bright as the sun, and the sun will shine seven times brighter than usual. It will be like the light of seven days all at once.

27.verse: Assyria Will Be Punished - The LORD is coming from far away with his fiery anger and thick clouds of smoke. His angry words flame up like a destructive fire;

28.verse: he breathes out a flood that comes up to the neck. He sifts the nations and destroys them. Then he puts a bridle in every foreigner’s mouth and leads them to doom.

29.verse: The LORD’s people will sing as they do when they celebrate a religious festival at night. The LORD is Israel’s mighty rock, and his people will be as happy as they are when they follow the sound of flutes to the mountain where he is worshiped.

30.verse: The LORD will get furious. His fearsome voice will be heard, his arm will be seen ready to strike, and his anger will be like a destructive fire, followed by thunderstorms and hailstones.

31.verse: When the Assyrians hear the LORD’s voice and see him striking with his iron rod, they will be terrified.

32.verse: He will attack them in battle, and each time he strikes them, it will be to the music of tambourines and harps.

33.verse: Long ago the LORD got a place ready for burning the body of the dead king. The place for the fire is deep and wide, the wood is piled high, and the LORD will start the fire by breathing out flaming sulfur.

1.verse: Don’t Trust the Power of Egypt - You are in for trouble if you go to Egypt for help, or if you depend on an army of chariots or a powerful cavalry. Instead you should depend on and trust the holy LORD God of Israel.

2.verse: The LORD isn’t stupid! He does what he promises, and he can bring doom. If you are cruel yourself, or help those who are evil, you will be destroyed.

3.verse: The Egyptians are mere humans. They aren’t God. Their horses are made of flesh; they can’t live forever. When the LORD shows his power, he will destroy the Egyptians and all who depend on them. Together they will fall.

4.verse: The LORD All-Powerful said to me, “I will roar and attack like a fearless lion not frightened by the shouts of shepherds trying to protect their sheep. That’s how I will come down and fight on Mount Zion.

5.verse: I, the LORD All-Powerful, will protect Jerusalem like a mother bird circling over her nest.”

6.verse: Come Back to the LORD - People of Israel, come back! You have completely turned from the LORD.

7.verse: The time is coming when you will throw away your idols of silver and gold, made by your sinful hands.

8.verse: The Assyrians will be killed, but not by the swords of humans. Their young men will try to escape, but they will be captured and forced into slavery.
