9.verse: Their fortress will fall when terror strikes; their army officers will be frightened and run from the battle. This is what the LORD has said, the LORD whose fiery furnace is built on Mount Zion.

1.verse: Justice Will Rule - A king and his leaders will rule with justice.

2.verse: They will be a place of safety from stormy winds, a stream in the desert, and a rock that gives shade from the heat of the sun.

3.verse: Then everyone who has eyes will open them and see, and those who have ears will pay attention.

4.verse: All who are impatient will take time to think; everyone who stutters will talk clearly.

5.verse: Fools will no longer be highly respected, and crooks won’t be given positions of honor.

6.verse: Fools talk foolishness. They always make plans to do sinful things, to lie about the LORD, to let the hungry starve, and to keep water from those who are thirsty.

7.verse: Cruel people tell lies— they do evil things, and make cruel plans to destroy the poor and needy, even when they beg for justice.

8.verse: But helpful people can always be trusted to make helpful plans.

9.verse: Punishment for the Women of Jerusalem - Listen to what I say, you women who are carefree and careless!

10.verse: You may not have worries now, but in about a year, the grape harvest will fail, and you will tremble.

11.verse: Shake and shudder, you women without a care! Strip off your clothes— put on sackcloth.

12.verse: Slap your breasts in sorrow because of what happened to the fruitful fields and vineyards,

13.verse: and to the happy homes in Jerusalem. The land of my people is covered with thorns.

14.verse: The palace will be deserted, the crowded city empty. Fortresses and towers will forever become playgrounds for wild donkeys and pastures for sheep.

15.verse: God’s Spirit Makes the Difference - When the Spirit is given to us from heaven, deserts will become orchards thick as fertile forests.

16.verse: Honesty and justice will prosper there,

17.verse: and justice will produce lasting peace and security.

18.verse: You, the LORD’s people, will live in peace, calm and secure,

19.verse: even if hailstones flatten forests and cities.

20.verse: You will have God’s blessing, as you plant your crops beside streams, while your donkeys and cattle roam freely about.

1.verse: Jerusalem Will Be Safe - You defeated my people. Now you’re in for trouble! You’ve never been destroyed, but you will be destroyed; you’ve never been betrayed, but you will be betrayed. When you have finished destroying and betraying, you will be destroyed and betrayed in return.

2.verse: Please, LORD, be kind to us! We depend on you. Make us strong each morning, and come to save us when we are in trouble.

3.verse: Nations scatter when you roar and show your greatness.

4.verse: We attack our enemies like swarms of locusts; we take everything that belongs to them.

5.verse: You, LORD, are above all others, and you live in the heavens. You have brought justice and fairness to Jerusalem;

6.verse: you are the foundation on which we stand today. You always save us and give true wisdom and knowledge. Nothing means more to us than obeying you.

7.verse: The LORD Will Do Something - Listen! Our bravest soldiers are running through the streets, screaming for help. Our messengers hoped for peace, but came home crying.

8.verse: No one travels anymore; every road is empty. Treaties are broken, and no respect is shown to any who keep promises.

9.verse: Fields are dry and barren; Mount Lebanon wilts with shame. Sharon Valley is a desert; the forests of Bashan and Carmel have lost their leaves.

10.verse: But the LORD says, “Now I will do something and be greatly praised.

11.verse: Your deeds are straw that will be set on fire by your very own breath.

12.verse: You will be burned to ashes like thorns in a fire.

13.verse: Everyone, both far and near, come look at what I have done. See my mighty power!”

14.verse: Punishment and Rewards - Those terrible sinners on Mount Zion tremble as they ask in fear, “How can we possibly live where a raging fire never stops burning?”

15.verse: But there will be rewards for those who live right and tell the truth, for those who refuse to take money by force or accept bribes, for all who hate murder and violent crimes.

16.verse: They will live in a fortress high on a rocky cliff, where they will have food and plenty of water.

17.verse: The LORD Is Our King - With your own eyes you will see the glorious King; you will see his kingdom reaching far and wide.

18.verse: Then you will ask yourself, “Where are those officials who terrified us and forced us to pay such heavy taxes?”

19.verse: You will never again have to see the proud people who spoke a strange and foreign language you could not understand.

20.verse: Look to Mount Zion where we celebrate our religious festivals. You will see Jerusalem, secure as a tent with pegs that cannot be pulled up and fastened with ropes that can never be broken.

21.verse: Our wonderful LORD will be with us! There will be deep rivers and wide streams safe from enemy ships.

22.verse: The LORD Is Our Judge - The LORD is our judge and our ruler; the LORD is our king and will keep us safe.

23.verse: But your nation is a ship with its rigging loose, its mast shaky, and its sail not spread. Someday even you that are lame will take everything you want from your enemies.

24.verse: The LORD will forgive your sins, and none of you will say, “I feel sick.”

1.verse: The Nations Will Be Judged - Everyone of every nation, the entire earth, and all of its creatures, come here and listen!

2.verse: The LORD is terribly angry with the nations; he has condemned them to be slaughtered.

3.verse: Their dead bodies will be left to rot and stink; their blood will flow down the mountains.

4.verse: Each star will disappear— the sky will roll up like a scroll. Everything in the sky will dry up and wilt like leaves on a vine or fruit on a tree.

5.verse: Trouble for Edom - After the sword of the LORD has done what it wants to the skies above, it will come down on Edom, the nation that the LORD has doomed for destruction.

6.verse: The sword of the LORD is covered with blood from lambs and goats, together with fat from kidneys of rams. This is because the LORD will slaughter many people and make a sacrifice of them in the city of Bozrah and everywhere else in Edom.

7.verse: Edom’s leaders are wild oxen. They are powerful bulls, but they will die with the others. Their country will be soaked with their blood, and its soil made fertile with their fat.

8.verse: The LORD has chosen the year and the day, when he will take revenge and come to Zion’s defense.

9.verse: Edom’s streams will turn into tar and its soil into sulfur— then the whole country will go up in flames.

10.verse: It will burn night and day and never stop smoking. Edom will be a desert, generation after generation; no one will ever travel through that land.

11.verse: Owls, hawks, and wild animals will make it their home. God will leave it in ruins, merely a pile of rocks.

12.verse: The End of Edom - Edom will be called “Kingdom of Nothing.” Its rulers will also be nothing.

13.verse: Its palaces and fortresses will be covered with thorns; only wolves and ostriches will make their home there.

14.verse: Wildcats and hyenas will hunt together, demons will scream to demons, and creatures of the night will live among the ruins.

15.verse: Owls will nest there to raise their young among its shadows, while families of buzzards circle around.

16.verse: In The Book of the LORD you can search and find where it is written, “The LORD brought together all of his creatures by the power of his Spirit. Not one is missing.”

17.verse: The LORD has decided where they each should live; they will be there forever, generation after generation.

1.verse: God’s Splendor Will Be Seen - Thirsty deserts will be glad; barren lands will celebrate and blossom with flowers.

2.verse: Deserts will bloom everywhere and sing joyful songs. They will be as majestic as Mount Lebanon, as glorious as Mount Carmel or Sharon Valley. Everyone will see the wonderful splendor of the LORD our God.

3.verse: God Changes Everything - Here is a message for all who are weak, trembling, and worried:

4.verse: “Cheer up! Don’t be afraid. Your God is coming to punish your enemies. God will take revenge on them and rescue you.”

5.verse: The blind will see, and the ears of the deaf will be healed.

6.verse: Those who were lame will leap around like deer; tongues once silent will begin to shout. Water will rush through the desert.

7.verse: Scorching sand will turn into a lake, and thirsty ground will flow with fountains. Grass will grow in wetlands, where packs of wild dogs once made their home.

8.verse: God’s Sacred Highway - A good road will be there, and it will be named “God’s Sacred Highway.” It will be for God’s people; no one unfit to worship God will walk on that road. And no fools can travel on that highway.

9.verse: No lions or other wild animals will come near that road; only those the LORD has saved will travel there.

10.verse: The people the LORD has rescued will come back singing as they enter Zion. Happiness will be a crown they will always wear. They will celebrate and shout because all sorrows and worries will be gone far away.

1.verse: The Assyrians Surround Jerusalem - Hezekiah had been king of Judah for fourteen years when King Sennacherib of Assyria invaded the country and captured every walled city

2.verse: except Jerusalem. The Assyrian king ordered his army commander to leave the city of Lachish and to take a large army to Jerusalem. The commander went there and stood on the road near the cloth makers' shops along the canal from the upper pool.

3.verse: Three of the king’s highest officials came out of Jerusalem to meet him. One of them was Hilkiah’s son Eliakim, who was the prime minister. The other two were Shebna, assistant to the prime minister, and Joah son of Asaph, keeper of the government records.

4.verse: The Assyrian commander told them: I have a message for Hezekiah from the great king of Assyria. Ask Hezekiah why he feels so sure of himself.

5.verse: Does he think he can plan and win a war with nothing but words? Who is going to help him, now that he has turned against the king of Assyria?

6.verse: Is he depending on Egypt and its king? That’s the same as leaning on a broken stick, and it will go right through his hand.

7.verse: Is Hezekiah now depending on the LORD, your God? Didn’t Hezekiah tear down all except one of the LORD’s altars and places of worship? Didn’t he tell the people of Jerusalem and Judah to worship at that one place?

8.verse: The king of Assyria wants to make a bet with you people! He will give you two thousand horses, if you have enough troops to ride them.

9.verse: How could you even defeat our lowest ranking officer, when you have to depend on Egypt for chariots and cavalry?

10.verse: Don’t forget that it was the LORD who sent me here with orders to destroy your nation!

11.verse: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said, “Sir, we don’t want the people listening from the city wall to understand what you are saying. So please speak to us in Aramaic instead of Hebrew.”

12.verse: The Assyrian army commander answered, “My king sent me to speak to everyone, not just to you leaders. These people will soon have to eat their own body waste and drink their own urine! And so will the three of you!”

13.verse: Then, in a voice loud enough for everyone to hear, he shouted out in Hebrew: Listen to what the great king of Assyria says!

14.verse: Don’t be fooled by Hezekiah. He can’t save you.

15.verse: Don’t trust him when he tells you that the LORD will protect you from the king of Assyria.

16.verse: Stop listening to Hezekiah. Pay attention to my king. Surrender to him. He will let you keep your own vineyards, fig trees, and cisterns

17.verse: for a while. Then he will come and take you away to a country just like yours, where you can plant vineyards and raise your own grain.

18.verse: Hezekiah claims the LORD will save you. But don’t be fooled by him. Were any other gods able to defend their land against the king of Assyria?

19.verse: What happened to the gods of Hamath, Arpad, and Sepharvaim? Were the gods of Samaria able to protect their land against the Assyrian forces?

20.verse: None of these gods kept their people safe from the king of Assyria. Do you think the LORD, your God, can do any better?

21.verse: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah had been warned by King Hezekiah not to answer the Assyrian commander. So they tore their clothes in sorrow and reported to Hezekiah everything the commander had said.

22.verse: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah had been warned by King Hezekiah not to answer the Assyrian commander. So they tore their clothes in sorrow and reported to Hezekiah everything the commander had said.

1.verse: Hezekiah Asks Isaiah for Advice - As soon as Hezekiah heard the news, he tore off his clothes in sorrow and put on sackcloth. Then he went into the temple of the LORD.

2.verse: He told Prime Minister Eliakim, Assistant Prime Minister Shebna, and the senior priests to dress in sackcloth and tell me:

3.verse: Isaiah, these are difficult and disgraceful times. Our nation is like a woman too weak to give birth, when it’s time for her baby to be born.

4.verse: Please pray for those of us who are left alive. The king of Assyria sent his army commander to insult the living God. Perhaps the LORD heard what he said and will do something, if you will pray.

5.verse: When these leaders came to me,

6.verse: I told them that the LORD had this message for Hezekiah: I am the LORD. Don’t worry about the insulting things that have been said about me by these messengers from the king of Assyria.

7.verse: I will upset him with rumors about what’s happening in his own country. He will go back, and there I will make him die a violent death.

8.verse: Meanwhile the commander of the Assyrian forces heard that his king had left the town of Lachish and was now attacking Libnah. So he went there.

9.verse: About this same time, the king of Assyria learned that King Tirhakah of Ethiopia was on his way to attack him. Then the king of Assyria sent some messengers with this note for Hezekiah:

10.verse: Don’t trust your God or be fooled by his promise to defend Jerusalem against me.

11.verse: You have heard how we Assyrian kings have completely wiped out other nations. What makes you feel so safe?

12.verse: The Assyrian kings before me destroyed the towns of Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and everyone from Eden who lived in Telassar. What good did their gods do them?

13.verse: The kings of Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah have all disappeared.

14.verse: Hezekiah Prays - After Hezekiah had read the note from the king of Assyria, he took it to the temple and spread it out for the LORD to see.

15.verse: Then he prayed:

16.verse: LORD God All-Powerful of Israel, your throne is above the winged creatures. You created the heavens and the earth, and you alone rule the kingdoms of this world.

17.verse: Just look and see how Sennacherib has insulted you, the living God.

18.verse: It is true, our LORD, that Assyrian kings have turned nations into deserts.

19.verse: They destroyed the idols of wood and stone that the people of those nations had made and worshiped.

20.verse: But you are our LORD and our God! We ask you to keep us safe from the Assyrian king. Then everyone in every kingdom on earth will know that you are the only LORD.

21.verse: Isaiah Gives the LORD’s Answer to Hezekiah - I went to Hezekiah and told him that the LORD God of Israel had said: Hezekiah, you prayed to me about King Sennacherib of Assyria. Now this is what I say to that king: The people of Jerusalem hate and make fun of you; they laugh behind your back.

22.verse: Isaiah Gives the LORD’s Answer to Hezekiah - I went to Hezekiah and told him that the LORD God of Israel had said: Hezekiah, you prayed to me about King Sennacherib of Assyria. Now this is what I say to that king: The people of Jerusalem hate and make fun of you; they laugh behind your back.

23.verse: Sennacherib, you cursed, shouted, and sneered at me, the holy God of Israel.

24.verse: You let your officials insult me, the Lord. And here is what you have said about yourself, “I led my chariots to the highest heights of Lebanon’s mountains. I went deep into its forest, cutting down the best cedar and cypress trees.

25.verse: I dried up every stream in the land of Egypt, and I drank water from wells I had dug.”

26.verse: Sennacherib, now listen to me, the LORD. I planned all of this long ago. And you don’t even know that I alone am the one who decided that you would do these things. I let you make ruins of fortified cities.

27.verse: Their people became weak, terribly confused. They were like wild flowers or like tender young grass growing on a flat roof or like a field of grain before it matures.

28.verse: I know all about you, even how fiercely angry you are with me.

29.verse: I have seen your pride and the tremendous hatred you have for me. Now I will put a hook in your nose, a bit in your mouth, then I will send you back to where you came from.

30.verse: Hezekiah, I will tell you what’s going to happen. This year you will eat crops that grow on their own, and the next year you will eat whatever springs up where those crops grew. But the third year, you will plant grain and vineyards, and you will eat what you harvest.

31.verse: Those who survive in Judah will be like a vine that puts down deep roots and bears fruit.

32.verse: I, the LORD All-Powerful, will see to it that some who live in Jerusalem will survive.

33.verse: I promise that the king of Assyria won’t get into Jerusalem, or shoot an arrow into the city, or even surround it and prepare to attack.

34.verse: As surely as I am the LORD, he will return by the way he came and will never enter Jerusalem.

35.verse: I will protect it for the sake of my own honor and because of the promise I made to my servant David.

36.verse: The Death of King Sennacherib - The LORD sent an angel to the camp of the Assyrians, and he killed one hundred eighty-five thousand of them all in one night. The next morning, the camp was full of dead bodies.

37.verse: After this, King Sennacherib went back to Assyria and lived in the city of Nineveh.

38.verse: One day he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, when his sons, Adrammelech and Sharezer, killed him with their swords. They escaped to the land of Ararat, and his son Esarhaddon became king.

1.verse: Hezekiah Gets Sick and Almost Dies - About this time, Hezekiah got sick and was almost dead. So I went in and told him, “The LORD says you won’t ever get well. You are going to die, and so you had better start doing what needs to be done.”

2.verse: Hezekiah turned toward the wall and prayed,

3.verse: “Don’t forget that I have been faithful to you, LORD. I have obeyed you with all my heart, and I do whatever you say is right.” After this, he cried hard.

4.verse: Then the LORD sent me

5.verse: with this message for Hezekiah: I am the LORD God, who was worshiped by your ancestor David. I heard you pray, and I saw you cry. I will let you live fifteen years more,

6.verse: while I protect you and your city from the king of Assyria.

7.verse: Now I will prove to you that I will keep my promise.

8.verse: Do you see the shadow made by the setting sun on the stairway built for King Ahaz? I will make the shadow go back ten steps. Then the shadow went back ten steps.

9.verse: King Hezekiah’s Song of Praise - This is what Hezekiah wrote after he got well:

10.verse: I thought I would die during my best years and stay as a prisoner forever in the world of the dead.

11.verse: I thought I would never again see you, my LORD, or any of the people who live on this earth.

12.verse: My life was taken from me like the tent that a shepherd pulls up and moves. You cut me off like thread from a weaver’s loom; you make a wreck of me day and night.

13.verse: Until morning came, I thought you would crush my bones just like a hungry lion; both night and day you make a wreck of me.

14.verse: I cry like a swallow; I mourn like a dove. My eyes are red from looking to you, LORD. I am terribly abused. Please come and help me.

15.verse: There’s nothing I can say in answer to you, since you are the one who has done this to me. My life has turned sour; I will limp until I die.

16.verse: Your words and your deeds bring life to everyone, including me. Please make me healthy and strong again.

17.verse: It was for my own good that I had such hard times. But your love protected me from doom in the deep pit, and you turned your eyes away from my sins.

18.verse: No one in the world of the dead can thank you or praise you; none of those in the deep pit can hope for you to show them how faithful you are.

19.verse: Only the living can thank you, as I am doing today. Each generation tells the next about your faithfulness.

20.verse: You, LORD, will save me, and every day that we live we will sing in your temple to the music of stringed instruments.

21.verse: Isaiah’s Advice to Hezekiah - I had told King Hezekiah’s servants to put some mashed figs on the king’s open sore, and he would get well.

22.verse: Then Hezekiah asked for proof that he would again worship in the LORD’s temple.

1.verse: Isaiah Speaks the LORD’s Message to Hezekiah - Merodach Baladan, the son of Baladan, was now king of Babylonia. And when he learned that Hezekiah was well, he sent messengers with letters and a gift for him.

2.verse: Hezekiah welcomed the messengers and showed them all the silver, the gold, the spices, and the fine oils that were in his storehouse. He even showed them where he kept his weapons. Nothing in his palace or in his entire kingdom was kept hidden from them.

3.verse: I asked Hezekiah, “Where did these men come from? What did they want?” “They came all the way from Babylonia,” Hezekiah answered.

4.verse: “What did you show them?” I asked. Hezekiah answered, “I showed them everything in my kingdom.”

5.verse: Then I told Hezekiah: I have a message for you from the LORD All-Powerful.

6.verse: One day everything you and your ancestors have stored up will be taken to Babylonia. The LORD has promised that nothing will be left.

7.verse: Some of your own sons will be taken to Babylonia, where they will be disgraced and made to serve in the king’s palace.

8.verse: Hezekiah thought, “At least our nation will be at peace for a while.” So he told me, “The message you brought from the LORD is good.”

1.verse: Encourage God’s People - Our God has said: “Encourage my people! Give them comfort.

2.verse: Speak kindly to Jerusalem and announce: Your slavery is past; your punishment is over. I, the LORD, made you pay double for your sins.”

3.verse: Someone is shouting: “Clear a path in the desert! Make a straight road for the LORD our God.

4.verse: Fill in the valleys; flatten every hill and mountain. Level the rough and rugged ground.

5.verse: Then the glory of the LORD will appear for all to see. The LORD has promised this!”

6.verse: Someone told me to shout, and I asked, “What should I shout?” We humans are merely grass, and we last no longer than wild flowers.

7.verse: At the LORD’s command, flowers and grass disappear, and so do we.

8.verse: Flowers and grass fade away, but what our God has said will never change.

9.verse: Your God Is Here! - There is good news for the city of Zion. Shout it as loud as you can from the highest mountain. Don’t be afraid to shout to the towns of Judah, “Your God is here!”

10.verse: Look! The powerful LORD God is coming to rule with his mighty arm. He brings with him what he has taken in war, and he rewards his people.

11.verse: The LORD cares for his nation, just as shepherds care for their flocks. He carries the lambs in his arms, while gently leading the mother sheep.

12.verse: Who Compares with God? - Did any of you measure the ocean by yourself or stretch out the sky with your own hands? Did you put the soil of the earth in a bucket or weigh the hills and mountains on balance scales?

13.verse: Has anyone told the LORD what he must do or given him advice?

14.verse: Did the LORD ask anyone to teach him wisdom and justice? Who gave him knowledge and understanding?

15.verse: To the LORD, all nations are merely a drop in a bucket or dust on balance scales; all of the islands are but a handful of sand.

16.verse: The cattle on Lebanon’s mountains would not be enough to offer as a sacrifice to God, and the trees would not be enough for the fire.

17.verse: God thinks of the nations as far less than nothing.

18.verse: Who compares with God? Is anything like him?

19.verse: Is an idol at all like God? It is made of bronze with a thin layer of gold, and decorated with silver.

20.verse: Or special wood may be chosen because it doesn’t rot— then skilled hands take care to make an idol that won’t fall on its face.

21.verse: God Rules the Whole Earth - Don’t you know? Haven’t you heard? Isn’t it clear that God created the world?

22.verse: God is the one who rules the whole earth, and we that live here are merely insects. He spread out the heavens like a curtain or an open tent.

23.verse: God brings down rulers and turns them into nothing.

24.verse: They are like flowers freshly sprung up and starting to grow. But when God blows on them, they wilt and are carried off like straw in a storm.

25.verse: The holy God asks, “Who compares with me? Is anyone my equal?”

26.verse: Look at the evening sky! Who created the stars? Who gave them each a name? Who leads them like an army? The LORD is so powerful that none of the stars are ever missing.

27.verse: The LORD Gives Strength - You people of Israel, say, “God pays no attention to us! He doesn’t care if we are treated unjustly.” But how can you say that?

28.verse: Don’t you know? Haven’t you heard? The LORD is the eternal God, Creator of the earth. He never gets weary or tired; his wisdom cannot be measured.

29.verse: The LORD gives strength to those who are weary.

30.verse: Even young people get tired, then stumble and fall.

31.verse: But those who trust the LORD will find new strength. They will be strong like eagles soaring upward on wings; they will walk and run without getting tired.

1.verse: The LORD Controls Human Events - Be silent and listen, every island in the sea. Have courage and come near, every one of you nations. Let’s settle this matter!

2.verse: Who appointed this ruler from the east? Who puts nations and kings in his power? His sword and his arrows turn them to dust blown by the wind.

3.verse: He goes after them so quickly that his feet barely touch the ground— he doesn’t even get hurt.

4.verse: Who makes these things happen? Who controls human events? I do! I am the LORD. I was there at the beginning; I will be there at the end.

5.verse: Islands and foreign nations saw what I did and trembled as they came near.

6.verse: What Can Idols Do? - Worshipers of idols comfort each other, saying, “Don’t worry!”

7.verse: Woodcarvers, goldsmiths, and other workers encourage one another and say, “We’ve done a great job!” Then they nail the idol down, so it won’t fall over.

8.verse: The LORD’s Chosen Servant - Israel, you are my servant. I chose you, the family of my friend Abraham.

9.verse: From far across the earth I brought you here and said, “You are my chosen servant. I haven’t forgotten you.”

10.verse: Don’t be afraid. I am with you. Don’t tremble with fear. I am your God. I will make you strong, as I protect you with my arm and give you victories.

11.verse: Everyone who hates you will be terribly disgraced; those who attack will vanish into thin air.

12.verse: You will look around for those brutal enemies, but you won’t find them because they will be gone.

13.verse: I am the LORD your God. I am holding your hand, so don’t be afraid. I am here to help you.

14.verse: People of Israel, don’t worry, though others may say, “Israel is only a worm!” I am the holy God of Israel, who saves and protects you.

15.verse: I will let you be like a log covered with sharp spikes. You will grind and crush every mountain and hill until they turn to dust.

16.verse: A strong wind will scatter them in all directions. Then you will celebrate and praise me, your LORD, the holy God of Israel.

17.verse: The LORD Helps the Poor - When the poor and needy are dying of thirst and cannot find water, I, the LORD God of Israel, will come to their rescue. I won’t forget them.

18.verse: I will make rivers flow on mountain peaks. I will send streams to fill the valleys. Dry and barren land will flow with springs and become a lake.

19.verse: I will fill the desert with all kinds of trees— cedars, acacias, and myrtles; olive and cypress trees; fir trees and pines.

20.verse: Everyone will see this and know that I, the holy LORD God of Israel, created it all.

21.verse: Idols Are Useless - I am the LORD, the King of Israel! Come argue your case with me. Present your evidence.

22.verse: Come near me, you idols. Tell us about the past, and we will think about it. Tell us about the future, so we will know what is going to happen.

23.verse: Prove that you are gods by making your predictions come true. Do something good or evil, so we can be amazed and terrified.

24.verse: You idols are nothing, and you are powerless. To worship you would be disgusting.

25.verse: I, the LORD, appointed a ruler in the north; now he comes from the east to honor my name. He tramples kings like mud, as potters trample clay.

26.verse: Did any of you idols predict what would happen? Did any of you get it right? None of you told about this or even spoke a word.

27.verse: I was the first to tell the people of Jerusalem, “Look, it’s happening!” I was the one who announced this good news to Zion.

28.verse: None of these idols are able to give advice or answer questions.

29.verse: They are nothing, and they can do nothing— they are less than a passing breeze.

1.verse: The LORD’s Servant - Here is my servant! I have made him strong. He is my chosen one; I am pleased with him. I have given him my Spirit, and he will bring justice to the nations.

2.verse: He won’t shout or yell or call out in the streets.

3.verse: He won’t break off a bent reed or put out a dying flame, but he will make sure that justice is done.

4.verse: He won’t quit or give up until he brings justice everywhere on earth, and people in foreign nations long for his teaching.

5.verse: I am the LORD God. I created the heavens like an open tent above. I made the earth and everything that grows on it. I am the source of life for all who live on this earth, so listen to what I say.

6.verse: I chose you to bring justice, and I am here at your side. I selected and sent you to bring light and my promise of hope to the nations.

7.verse: You will give sight to the blind; you will set prisoners free from dark dungeons.

8.verse: My name is the LORD! I won’t let idols or humans share my glory and praise.

9.verse: Everything has happened just as I said it would; now I will announce what will happen next.

10.verse: Sing Praises to the LORD - Tell the whole world to sing a new song to the LORD! Tell those who sail the ocean and those who live far away to join in the praise.

11.verse: Tell the tribes of the desert and everyone in the mountains to celebrate and sing.

12.verse: Let them announce his praises everywhere.

13.verse: The LORD is marching out like an angry soldier, shouting with all his might while attacking his enemies.

14.verse: The LORD Will Help His People - For a long time, I, the LORD, have held my temper; now I will scream and groan like a woman giving birth.

15.verse: I will destroy the mountains and what grows on them; I will dry up rivers and ponds.

16.verse: I will lead the blind on roads they have never known; I will guide them on paths they have never traveled. Their road is dark and rough, but I will give light to keep them from stumbling. This is my solemn promise.

17.verse: Everyone who worships idols as though they were gods will be terribly ashamed.

18.verse: God’s People Won’t Obey - You people are deaf and blind, but the LORD commands you to listen and to see.

19.verse: No one is as blind or deaf as his messenger, his chosen servant,

20.verse: who sees and hears so much, but pays no attention.

21.verse: The LORD always does right, and so he wanted his Law to be greatly praised.

22.verse: But his people were trapped and imprisoned in holes with no one to rescue them. All they owned had been taken, and no one was willing to give it back.

23.verse: Why won’t his people ever learn to listen?

24.verse: Israel sinned and refused to obey the LORD or follow his instructions. So the LORD let them be robbed of everything they owned.

25.verse: He was furious with them and punished their nation with the fires of war. Still they paid no attention. They didn’t even care when they were surrounded and scorched by flames.

1.verse: The LORD Has Rescued His People - Descendants of Jacob, I, the LORD, created you and formed your nation. Israel, don’t be afraid. I have rescued you. I have called you by name; now you belong to me.

2.verse: When you cross deep rivers, I will be with you, and you won’t drown. When you walk through fire, you won’t be burned or scorched by the flames.

3.verse: I am the LORD, your God, the Holy One of Israel, the God who saves you. I gave up Egypt, Ethiopia, and the region of Seba in exchange for you.

4.verse: To me, you are very dear, and I love you. That’s why I gave up nations and people to rescue you.

5.verse: Don’t be afraid! I am with you. From both east and west I will bring you together.

6.verse: I will say to the north and to the south, “Free my sons and daughters! Let them return from distant lands.

7.verse: They are my people— I created each of them to bring honor to me.”

8.verse: The LORD Alone Is God - The LORD said: Bring my people together. They have eyes and ears, but they can’t see or hear.

9.verse: Tell everyone of every nation to gather around. None of them can honestly say, “We told you so!” If someone heard them say this, then tell us about it now.

10.verse: My people, you are my witnesses and my chosen servant. I want you to know me, to trust me, and understand that I alone am God. I have always been God; there can be no others.

11.verse: I alone am the LORD; only I can rescue you.

12.verse: I promised to save you, and I kept my promise. You are my witnesses that no other god did this. I, the LORD, have spoken.

13.verse: I am God now and forever. No one can snatch you from me or stand in my way.

14.verse: The LORD Will Prepare the Way - I, the LORD, will rescue you! I am Israel’s holy God, and this is my promise: For your sake, I will send an army against Babylon to drag its people away, crying as they go.

15.verse: I am the LORD, your holy God, Israel’s Creator and King.

16.verse: I am the one who cut a path through the mighty ocean.

17.verse: I sent an army to chase you with chariots and horses; now they lie dead, unable to move. They are like an oil lamp with the flame snuffed out.

18.verse: Forget the Past - The LORD said: Forget what happened long ago! Don’t think about the past.

19.verse: I am creating something new. There it is! Do you see it? I have put roads in deserts, streams in thirsty lands.

20.verse: Every wild animal honors me, even jackals and owls. I provide water in deserts— streams in thirsty lands for my chosen people.

21.verse: I made them my own nation, so they would praise me.

22.verse: I, the LORD, said to Israel: You have become weary, but not from worshiping me.

23.verse: You have not honored me by sacrificing sheep or other animals. And I have not burdened you with demands for sacrifices or sweet-smelling incense.

24.verse: You have not brought delicious spices for me or given me the best part of your sacrificed animals. Instead, you burden me down with your terrible sins.

25.verse: But I wipe away your sins because of who I am. And so, I will forget the wrongs you have done.

26.verse: Meet me in court! State your case and prove that you are right.

27.verse: Your earliest ancestor and all of your leaders rebelled against me.

28.verse: That’s why I don’t allow your priests to serve me; I let Israel be destroyed and your people disgraced.

1.verse: The LORD’s Promise to Israel - People of Israel, I have chosen you as my servant.

2.verse: I am your Creator. You were in my care even before you were born. Israel, don’t be terrified! You are my chosen servant, my very favorite.

3.verse: I will bless the thirsty land by sending streams of water; I will bless your descendants by giving them my Spirit.

4.verse: They will spring up like grass or like willow trees near flowing streams.

5.verse: They will worship me and become my people. They will write my name on the back of their hands.

6.verse: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the first and the last, the one and only God. Israel, I have rescued you! I am your King.

7.verse: Can anyone compare with me? If so, let them speak up and tell me now. Let them say what has happened since I made my nation long ago, and let them tell what is going to happen.

8.verse: Don’t tremble with fear! Didn’t I tell you long ago? Didn’t you hear me? I alone am God— no one else is a mighty rock.

9.verse: Idols Can’t Do a Thing - The LORD said: Those people who make idols are nothing themselves, and the idols they treasure are just as worthless. Worshipers of idols are blind, stupid, and foolish.

10.verse: Why make an idol or an image that can’t do a thing?

11.verse: Everyone who makes idols and all who worship them are mere humans, who will end up sadly disappointed. Let them face me in court and be terrified.

12.verse: Idols and Firewood - A metalworker shapes an idol by using a hammer and heat from the fire. In his powerful hand he holds a hammer, as he pounds the metal into the proper shape. But he gets hungry and thirsty and loses his strength.

13.verse: Some woodcarver measures a piece of wood, then draws an outline. The idol is carefully carved with each detail exact. At last it looks like a person and is placed in a temple.

14.verse: Either cedar, cypress, oak, or any tree from the forest may be chosen. Or even a pine tree planted by the woodcarver and watered by the rain.

15.verse: Some of the wood is used to make a fire for heating or for cooking. One piece is made into an idol, then the woodcarver bows down and worships it.

16.verse: He enjoys the warm fire and the meat that was roasted over the burning coals.

17.verse: Afterwards, he bows down to worship the wooden idol. “Protect me!” he says. “You are my god.”

18.verse: Those who worship idols are stupid and blind!

19.verse: They don’t have enough sense to say to themselves, “I made a fire with half of the wood and cooked my bread and meat on it. Then I made something worthless with the other half. Why worship a block of wood?”

20.verse: How can anyone be stupid enough to trust something that can be burned to ashes? No one can save themselves like that. Don’t they realize that the idols they hold in their hands are not really gods?

21.verse: The LORD Won’t Forget His People - People of Israel, you are my servant, so remember all of this. Israel, I created you, and you are my servant. I won’t forget you.

22.verse: Turn back to me! I have rescued you and swept away your sins as though they were clouds.

23.verse: Sing Praises to the LORD - Tell the heavens and the earth to start singing! Tell the mountains and every tree in the forest to join in the song! The LORD has rescued his people; now they will worship him.

24.verse: The LORD Created Everything - Israel, I am your LORD. I am your source of life, and I have rescued you. I created everything from the sky above to the earth below.

25.verse: I make liars of false prophets and fools of fortunetellers. I take human wisdom and turn it into nonsense.

26.verse: I will make the message of my prophets come true. They are saying, “Jerusalem will be filled with people, and the LORD will rebuild the towns of Judah.”

27.verse: I am the one who commands the sea and its streams to run dry.

28.verse: I am also the one who says, “Cyrus will lead my people and obey my orders. Jerusalem and the temple will be rebuilt.”

1.verse: Cyrus Obeys the LORD’s Commands - The LORD said to Cyrus, his chosen one: I have taken hold of your right hand to help you capture nations and remove kings from power. City gates will open for you; not one will stay closed.

2.verse: As I lead you, I will level mountains and break the iron bars on bronze gates of cities.

3.verse: I will give you treasures hidden in dark and secret places. Then you will know that I, the LORD God of Israel, have called you by name.

4.verse: Cyrus, you don’t even know me! But I have called you by name and highly honored you because of Israel, my chosen servant.

5.verse: Only I am the LORD! There are no other gods. I have made you strong, though you don’t know me.

6.verse: Now everyone from east to west will learn that I am the LORD. No other gods are real.

7.verse: I create light and darkness, happiness and sorrow. I, the LORD, do all of this.

8.verse: Tell the heavens to send down justice like showers of rain. Prepare the earth for my saving power to sprout and produce justice that I, the LORD, create.

9.verse: The LORD’s Mighty Power - The LORD said: Israel, you have no right to argue with your Creator. You are merely a clay pot shaped by a potter. The clay doesn’t ask, “Why did you make me this way? Where are the handles?”

10.verse: Children don’t have the right to demand of their parents, “What have you done to make us what we are?”

11.verse: I am the LORD, the Creator, the holy God of Israel. Do you dare question me about my own nation or about what I have done?

12.verse: I created the world and covered it with people; I stretched out the sky and filled it with stars.

13.verse: I have done the right thing by placing Cyrus in power, and I will make the roads easy for him to follow. I am the LORD All-Powerful! Cyrus will rebuild my city and set my people free without being paid a thing. I, the LORD, have spoken.

14.verse: The LORD Alone Can Save - My people, I, the LORD, promise that the riches of Egypt and the treasures of Ethiopia will belong to you. You will force into slavery those tall people of Seba. They will bow down and say, “The only true God is with you; there are no other gods.”

15.verse: People of Israel, your God is a mystery, though he alone can save.

16.verse: Anyone who makes idols will be confused and terribly disgraced.

17.verse: But Israel, I, the LORD, will always keep you safe and free from shame.

18.verse: Everyone Is Invited - The LORD alone is God! He created the heavens and made a world where people can live, instead of creating an empty desert. The LORD alone is God; there are no others.

19.verse: The LORD did not speak in a dark secret place or command Jacob’s descendants to search for him in vain. The LORD speaks the truth, and this is what he says

20.verse: to every survivor from every nation: “Gather around me! Learn how senseless it is to worship wooden idols or pray to helpless gods.

21.verse: “Why don’t you get together and meet me in court? Didn’t I tell you long ago what would happen? I am the only God! There are no others. I bring about justice, and have the power to save.

22.verse: “I invite the whole world to turn to me and be saved. I alone am God! No others are real.

23.verse: I have made a solemn promise, one that won’t be broken: Everyone will bow down and worship me.

24.verse: They will admit that I alone can bring about justice. Everyone who is angry with me will be terribly ashamed and will turn to me.

25.verse: I, the LORD, will give victory and great honor to the people of Israel.”

1.verse: Babylonia’s Gods Are Helpless - The LORD said: The gods Bel and Nebo are down on their knees, as wooden images of them are carried away on weary animals.

2.verse: They are down on their knees to rescue the heavy load, but the images are still taken to a foreign country.

3.verse: You survivors in Israel, listen to me, the LORD. Since the day you were born, I have carried you along.

4.verse: I will still be the same when you are old and gray, and I will take care of you. I created you. I will carry you and always keep you safe.

5.verse: Can anyone compare with me? Is anyone my equal?

6.verse: Some people hire a goldsmith and give silver and gold to be formed into an idol for them to worship.

7.verse: They carry the idol on their shoulders, then put it on a stand, but it cannot move. They call out to the idol when they are in trouble, but it doesn’t answer, and it cannot help.

8.verse: Now keep this in mind, you sinful people. And don’t ever forget it.

9.verse: The LORD Alone Is God - I alone am God! There are no other gods; no one is like me. Think about what happened many years ago.

10.verse: From the very beginning, I told what would happen long before it took place. I kept my word

11.verse: and brought someone from a distant land to do what I wanted. He attacked from the east, like a hawk swooping down. Now I will keep my promise and do what I planned.

12.verse: You people are stubborn and far from being safe, so listen to me.

13.verse: I will soon come to save you. I am not far away and will waste no time; I take pride in Israel and will save Jerusalem.

1.verse: Babylon Will Fall - The LORD said: City of Babylon, You are delicate and untouched, but that will change. Surrender your royal power and sit in the dirt.

2.verse: Start grinding grain! Take off your veil. Strip off your fancy clothes and cross over rivers.

3.verse: You will suffer the shame of going naked, because I will take revenge, and no one can escape.

4.verse: I am the LORD All-Powerful, the holy God of Israel. I am their Savior.

5.verse: Babylon, be silent! Sit in the dark. No longer will nations accept you as their queen.

6.verse: I was angry with my people. So I let you take their land and bring disgrace on them. You showed them no mercy, but were especially cruel to those who were old.

7.verse: You thought that you would be queen forever. You didn’t care what you did; it never entered your mind that you might get caught.

8.verse: You think that you alone are all-powerful, that you won’t be a widow or lose your children. All you care about is pleasure, but listen to what I say.

9.verse: Your magic powers and charms will suddenly fail, then you will be a widow and lose your children.

10.verse: You hid behind evil like a shield and said, “No one can see me!” You were fooled by your wisdom and your knowledge; you felt sure that you alone were in full control.

11.verse: But without warning, disaster will strike— and your magic charms won’t help at all.

12.verse: Keep using your magic powers and your charms as you have always done. Maybe—just maybe— you will frighten somebody!

13.verse: You have worn yourself out, asking for advice from those who study the stars and tell the future month after month. Go ask them how to be saved from what will happen.

14.verse: People who trust the stars are as helpless as straw in a flaming fire. No one can even keep warm, sitting by a fire that feeds only on straw.

15.verse: These are the fortunetellers you have done business with all of your life. But they don’t know where they are going, and they can’t save you.

1.verse: The LORD Corrects His People - People of Israel, you come from Jacob’s family and the tribe of Judah. You claim to worship me, the LORD God of Israel, but you are lying.

2.verse: You call Jerusalem your home and say you depend on me, the LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel.

3.verse: Long ago I announced what was going to be, then without warning, I made it happen.

4.verse: I knew you were stubborn and hardheaded.

5.verse: And I told you these things, so that when they happened you would not say, “The idols we worship did this.”

6.verse: You heard what I said, and you have seen it happen. Now admit that it’s true! I will show you secrets you have never known.

7.verse: Today I am doing something new, something you cannot say you have heard before.

8.verse: You have never been willing to listen to what I say; from the moment of your birth, I knew you would rebel.

9.verse: The LORD Warns Israel - I, the LORD, am true to myself; I will be praised for not punishing and destroying you.

10.verse: I tested you in hard times just as silver is refined in a heated furnace.

11.verse: I did this because of who I am. I refuse to be dishonored or share my praise with any other god.

12.verse: Israel, my chosen people, listen to me. I alone am the LORD, the first and the last.

13.verse: With my own hand I created the earth and stretched out the sky. They obey my every command.

14.verse: The LORD Speaks to the Nations - Gather around me, all of you! Listen to what I say. Did any of your idols predict this would happen? Did they say that my friend would do what I want done to Babylonia?

15.verse: I was the one who chose him. I have brought him this far, and he will be successful.

16.verse: Come closer and listen! I have never kept secret the things I have said, and I was here before time began. It Is Best To Obey the LORD - By the power of his Spirit the LORD God has sent me

17.verse: with this message: People of Israel, I am the holy LORD God, the one who rescues you. For your own good, I teach you, and I lead you along the right path.

18.verse: How I wish that you had obeyed my commands! Your success and good fortune would then have overflowed like a flooding river.

19.verse: Your nation would be blessed with more people than there are grains of sand along the seashore. And I would never have let your country be destroyed.

20.verse: Now leave Babylon! Celebrate as you go. Be happy and shout for everyone to hear, “The LORD has rescued his servant Israel!

21.verse: He led us through the desert and made water flow from a rock to satisfy our thirst.

22.verse: But the LORD has promised that none who are evil will live in peace.”

1.verse: The Work of the LORD’s Servant - Everyone, listen, even you foreign nations across the sea. The LORD chose me and gave me a name before I was born.

2.verse: He made my words pierce like a sharp sword or a pointed arrow; he kept me safely hidden in the palm of his hand.

3.verse: The LORD said to me, “Israel, you are my servant; and because of you I will be highly honored.”

4.verse: I said to myself, “I’m completely worn out; my time has been wasted. But I did it for the LORD God, and he will reward me.”

5.verse: Even before I was born, the LORD God chose me to serve him and to lead back the people of Israel. So the LORD has honored me and made me strong.

6.verse: Now the LORD says to me, “It isn’t enough for you to be merely my servant. You must do more than lead back survivors from the tribes of Israel. I have placed you here as a light for other nations; you must take my saving power to everyone on earth.”

7.verse: The LORD Will Rescue His People - Israel, I am the holy LORD God, the one who rescues you. You are slaves of rulers and of a nation who despises you. Now this is what I promise: Kings and rulers will honor you by kneeling at your feet. You can trust me! I am your LORD, the holy God of Israel, and you are my chosen ones.

8.verse: The LORD Will Lead His People Home - This is what the LORD says: I will answer your prayers because I have set a time when I will help by coming to save you. I have chosen you to take my promise of hope to other nations. You will rebuild the country from its ruins, then people will come and settle there.

9.verse: You will set prisoners free from dark dungeons to see the light of day. On their way home, they will find plenty to eat, even on barren hills.

10.verse: They won’t go hungry or get thirsty; they won’t be bothered by the scorching sun or hot desert winds. I will be merciful while leading them along to streams of water.

11.verse: I will level the mountains and make roads.

12.verse: Then my people will return from distant lands in the north and the west and from the city of Syene.

13.verse: The LORD’s Mercy - Tell the heavens and the earth to celebrate and sing; command every mountain to join in the song. The LORD’s people have suffered, but he has shown mercy and given them comfort.

14.verse: The people of Zion said, “The LORD has turned away and forgotten us.”

15.verse: The LORD answered, “Could a mother forget a child who nurses at her breast? Could she fail to love an infant who came from her own body? Even if a mother could forget, I will never forget you.

16.verse: A picture of your city is drawn on my hand. You are always in my thoughts!

17.verse: “Your city will be built faster than it was destroyed— those who attacked it will retreat and leave.

18.verse: Look around! You will see your people coming home. As surely as I live, I, the LORD, promise that your city with its people will be as lovely as a bride wearing her jewelry.”

19.verse: Jerusalem’s Bright Future - Jerusalem is now in ruins! Nothing is left of the city. But it will be rebuilt and soon overcrowded; its cruel enemies will be gone far away.

20.verse: Jerusalem is a woman whose children were born while she was in deep sorrow over the loss of her husband. Now those children will come and seek room in the crowded city,

21.verse: and Jerusalem will ask, “Am I really their mother? How could I have given birth when I was still mourning in a foreign land? Who raised these children? Where have they come from?”

22.verse: The LORD God says: “I will soon give a signal for the nations to return your sons and your daughters to the arms of Jerusalem.

23.verse: The kings and queens of those nations where they were raised will come and bow down. They will take care of you just like a slave taking care of a child. Then you will know that I am the LORD. You won’t be disappointed if you trust me.”

24.verse: The LORD Is on Our Side - Is it possible to rescue victims from someone strong and cruel?

25.verse: But the LORD has promised to fight on our side and to rescue our children from those strong and violent enemies.

26.verse: He will make those cruel people dine on their own flesh and get drunk from drinking their own blood. Then everyone will know that the LORD is our Savior; the powerful God of Israel has rescued his people.

1.verse: The LORD’s Power To Punish - The LORD says, “Children, I didn’t divorce your mother or sell you to pay debts; I divorced her and sold you because of your sins.

2.verse: I came and called out, but you didn’t answer. Have I lost my power to rescue and save? At my command oceans and rivers turn into deserts; fish rot and stink for lack of water.

3.verse: I make the sky turn dark like the sackcloth you wear at funerals.”

4.verse: God’s Servant Must Suffer - The LORD God gives me the right words to encourage the weary. Each morning he awakens me eager to learn his teaching;

5.verse: he made me willing to listen and not rebel or run away.

6.verse: I let them beat my back and pull out my beard. I didn’t turn aside when they insulted me and spit in my face.

7.verse: But the LORD God keeps me from being disgraced. So I refuse to give up, because I know God will never let me down.

8.verse: My protector is nearby; no one can stand here to accuse me of wrong.

9.verse: The LORD God will help me and prove I am innocent. My accusers will wear out like moth-eaten clothes.

10.verse: None of you respect the LORD or obey his servant. You walk in the dark instead of the light; you don’t trust the name of the LORD your God.

11.verse: Go ahead and walk in the light of the fires you have set. But with his own hand, the LORD will punish you and make you suffer.

1.verse: The LORD Will Bring Comfort - If you want to do right and obey the LORD, follow Abraham’s example. He was the rock from which you were chipped.

2.verse: God chose Abraham and Sarah to be your ancestors. The LORD blessed Abraham, and from that one man came many descendants.

3.verse: Though Zion is in ruins, the LORD will bring comfort, and the city will be as lovely as the garden of Eden that he provided. Then Zion will celebrate; it will be thankful and sing joyful songs.

4.verse: The LORD’s Victory Will Last - The LORD says: You are my people and nation! So pay attention to me. My teaching will cause justice to shine like a light for every nation.

5.verse: Those who live across the sea are eagerly waiting for me to rescue them. I am strong and ready; soon I will come to save and to rule all nations.

6.verse: Look closely at the sky! Stare at the earth. The sky will vanish like smoke; the earth will wear out like clothes. Everyone on this earth will die like flies. But my victory will last; my saving power never ends.

7.verse: If you want to do right and to obey my teaching with all your heart, then pay close attention. Don’t be discouraged when others insult you and say hurtful things.

8.verse: They will be eaten away like a moth-eaten coat. But my victory will last; my saving power will never end.

9.verse: A Prayer for the LORD’s Help - Wake up! Do something, LORD. Be strong and ready. Wake up! Do what you did for our people long ago. Didn’t you chop up Rahab the monster?

10.verse: Didn’t you dry up the deep sea and make a road for your people to follow safely across?

11.verse: Now those you have rescued will return to Jerusalem, singing on their way. They will be crowned with great happiness, never again to be burdened with sadness and sorrow.

12.verse: The LORD Gives Hope - I am the LORD, the one who encourages you. Why are you afraid of mere humans? They dry up and die like grass.

13.verse: I spread out the heavens and laid foundations for the earth. But you have forgotten me, your LORD and Creator. All day long you were afraid of those who were angry and hoped to abuse you. Where are they now?

14.verse: Everyone crying out in pain will be quickly set free; they will be rescued from the power of death and never go hungry.

15.verse: I will help them because I am your God, the LORD All-Powerful, who makes the ocean roar.

16.verse: I have told you what to say, and I will keep you safe in the palm of my hand. I spread out the heavens and laid foundations for the earth. Now I say, “Jerusalem, your people are mine.”

17.verse: A Warning to Jerusalem - Jerusalem, wake up! Stand up! You’ve drunk too much from the cup filled with the LORD’s anger. You have swallowed every drop, and you can’t walk straight.

18.verse: Not one of your many children is there to guide you or to offer a helping hand.

19.verse: You have been destroyed by war and by famine; I cannot comfort you.

20.verse: The LORD your God is angry, and on every street corner your children lie helpless, like deer trapped in nets.

21.verse: You are in trouble and drunk, but not from wine. So pay close attention

22.verse: to the LORD your God, who defends you and says, “I have taken from your hands the cup filled with my anger that made you drunk. You will never be forced to drink it again.

23.verse: Instead I will give it to your brutal enemies, who treated you like dirt and walked all over you.”

1.verse: Jerusalem Can Celebrate - Jerusalem, wake up! Stand up and be strong. Holy city of Zion, dress in your best clothes. Those foreigners who ruined your sacred city won’t bother you again.

2.verse: Zion, rise from the dirt! Free yourself from the rope around your neck.

3.verse: Suffering Will End - The LORD says: My people, you were sold, but not for money; now you will be set free, but not for a payment.

4.verse: Long ago you went to Egypt where you lived as foreigners. Then Assyria was cruel to you,

5.verse: and now another nation has taken you prisoner for no reason at all. Your leaders groan with pain, and day after day my own name is cursed.

6.verse: My people, you will learn who I am and who is speaking because I am here.

7.verse: A Message of Hope for Jerusalem - What a beautiful sight! On the mountains a messenger announces to Jerusalem, “Good news! You’re saved. There will be peace. Your God is now King.”

8.verse: Everyone on guard duty, sing and celebrate! Look! You can see the LORD returning to Zion.

9.verse: Jerusalem, rise from the ruins! Join in the singing. The LORD has given comfort to his people; he comes to your rescue.

10.verse: The LORD has shown all nations his mighty strength; now everyone will see the saving power of our God.

11.verse: A Command To Leave Babylon - Leave the city of Babylon! Don’t touch anything filthy. Wash yourselves. Be ready to carry back everything sacred that belongs to the LORD.

12.verse: You won’t need to run. No one is chasing you. The LORD God of Israel will lead and protect you from enemy attacks.

13.verse: The Suffering Servant - The LORD says: My servant will succeed! He will be given great praise and the highest honors.

14.verse: Many were horrified at what happened to him. But everyone who saw him was even more horrified because he suffered until he no longer looked human.

15.verse: My servant will make nations worthy to worship me; kings will be silent as they bow in wonder. They will see and think about things they have never seen or thought about before.

1.verse: What God’s Servant Did for Us - Has anyone believed us or seen the mighty power of the LORD in action?

2.verse: Like a young plant or a root that sprouts in dry ground, the servant grew up obeying the LORD. He wasn’t some handsome king. Nothing about the way he looked made him attractive to us.

3.verse: He was hated and rejected; his life was filled with sorrow and terrible suffering. No one wanted to look at him. We despised him and said, “He is a nobody!”

4.verse: He suffered and endured great pain for us, but we thought his suffering was punishment from God.

5.verse: He was wounded and crushed because of our sins; by taking our punishment, he made us completely well.

6.verse: All of us were like sheep that had wandered off. We had each gone our own way, but the LORD gave him the punishment we deserved.

7.verse: He was painfully abused, but he did not complain. He was silent like a lamb being led to the butcher, as quiet as a sheep having its wool cut off.

8.verse: He was condemned to death without a fair trial. Who could have imagined what would happen to him? His life was taken away because of the sinful things my people had done.

9.verse: He wasn’t dishonest or violent, but he was buried in a tomb of cruel and rich people.

10.verse: The LORD decided his servant would suffer as a sacrifice to take away the sin and guilt of others. Now the servant will live to see his own descendants. He did everything the LORD had planned.

11.verse: By suffering, the servant will learn the true meaning of obeying the LORD. Although he is innocent, he will take the punishment for the sins of others, so that many of them will no longer be guilty.

12.verse: The LORD will reward him with honor and power for sacrificing his life. Others thought he was a sinner, but he suffered for our sins and asked God to forgive us.

1.verse: A Promise of the LORD’s Protection - Sing and shout, even though you have never had children! The LORD has promised that you will have more children than someone married for a long time.

2.verse: Make your tents larger! Spread out the tent pegs; fasten them firmly.

3.verse: You and your descendants will take over the land of other nations. You will settle in towns that are now in ruins.

4.verse: Don’t be afraid or ashamed and don’t be discouraged. You won’t be disappointed. Forget how sinful you were when you were young; stop feeling ashamed for being left a widow.

5.verse: The LORD All-Powerful, the Holy God of Israel, rules all the earth. He is your Creator and husband, and he will rescue you.

6.verse: You were like a young wife, brokenhearted and crying because her husband had divorced her. But the LORD your God says, “I am taking you back!

7.verse: I rejected you for a while, but with love and tenderness I will embrace you again.

8.verse: For a while, I turned away in furious anger. Now I will have mercy and love you forever! I, your protector and LORD, make this promise.”

9.verse: The LORD Promises Lasting Peace - I once promised Noah that I would never again destroy the earth by a flood. Now I have promised that I will never again get angry and punish you.

10.verse: Every mountain and hill may disappear. But I will always be kind and merciful to you; I won’t break my agreement to give your nation peace.

11.verse: The New Jerusalem - Jerusalem, you are sad and discouraged, tossed around in a storm. But I, the LORD, will rebuild your city with precious stones; for your foundation I will use blue sapphires.

12.verse: Your fortresses will be built of rubies, your gates of jewels, and your walls of gems.

13.verse: I will teach your children and make them successful.

14.verse: You will be built on fairness with no fears of injustice; every one of your worries will be taken far from you.

15.verse: I will never send anyone to attack your city, and you will make prisoners of those who do attack.

16.verse: Don’t forget that I created metalworkers who make weapons over burning coals. I also created armies that can bring destruction.

17.verse: Weapons made to attack you won’t be successful; words spoken against you won’t hurt at all. My servants, Jerusalem is yours! I, the LORD, promise to bless you with victory.

1.verse: The LORD’s Invitation - If you are thirsty, come and drink water! If you don’t have any money, come, eat what you want! Drink wine and milk without paying a cent.

2.verse: Why waste your money on what really isn’t food? Why work hard for something that doesn’t satisfy? Listen carefully to me, and you will enjoy the very best foods.

3.verse: Pay close attention! Come to me and live. I will promise you the eternal love and loyalty that I promised David.

4.verse: I made him the leader and ruler of the nations; he was my witness to them.

5.verse: You will call out to nations you have never known. And they have never known you, but they will come running because I am the LORD, the holy God of Israel, and I have honored you.

6.verse: God’s Words Are Powerful - Turn to the LORD! He can still be found. Call out to God! He is near.

7.verse: Give up your crooked ways and your evil thoughts. Return to the LORD our God. He will be merciful and forgive your sins.

8.verse: The LORD says: “My thoughts and my ways are not like yours.

9.verse: Just as the heavens are higher than the earth, my thoughts and my ways are higher than yours.

10.verse: “Rain and snow fall from the sky. But they don’t return without watering the earth that produces seeds to plant and grain to eat.

11.verse: That’s how it is with my words. They don’t return to me without doing everything I send them to do.”

12.verse: God’s People Will Celebrate - When you are set free, you will celebrate and travel home in peace. Mountains and hills will sing as you pass by, and trees will clap.

13.verse: Cypress and myrtle trees will grow in fields once covered by thorns. And then those trees will stand as a lasting witness to the glory of the LORD.

1.verse: All Nations Will Be Part of God’s People - The LORD said: Be honest and fair! Soon I will come to save you; my saving power will be seen everywhere on earth.

2.verse: I will bless everyone who respects the Sabbath and refuses to do wrong.

3.verse: Foreigners who worship me must not say, “The LORD won’t let us be part of his people.” Men who are unable to become fathers must no longer say, “We are dried-up trees.”

4.verse: To them, I, the LORD, say: Respect the Sabbath, obey me completely, and keep our agreement.

5.verse: Then I will set up monuments in my temple with your names written on them. This will be much better than having children, because these monuments will stand there forever.

6.verse: Foreigners will follow me. They will love me and worship in my name; they will respect the Sabbath and keep our agreement.

7.verse: I will bring them to my holy mountain, where they will celebrate in my house of worship. Their sacrifices and offerings will always be welcome on my altar. Then my house will be known as a house of worship for all nations.

8.verse: I, the LORD, promise to bring together my people who were taken away, and let them join the others.

9.verse: God Promises To Punish Israel’s Leaders - Come from the forest, you wild animals! Attack and gobble down your victims.

10.verse: You leaders of Israel should be watchdogs, protecting my people. But you can’t see a thing, and you never warn them. Dozing and daydreaming are all you ever do.

11.verse: You stupid leaders are a pack of hungry and greedy dogs that never get enough. You are shepherds who mistreat your own sheep for selfish gain.

12.verse: You say to each other, “Let’s drink till we’re drunk! Tomorrow we’ll do it again. We’ll really enjoy ourselves.”

1.verse: God’s Faithful People Suffer - God’s faithful people are dragged off and killed, and no one even cares. Evil sweeps them away,

2.verse: but in death they find peace for obeying God.

3.verse: The LORD Condemns Idolatry - You people are unfaithful! You go to fortunetellers, and you worship idols. Now pay close attention!

4.verse: Who are you making fun of? Who are you sneering at? Look how your sins have made fools of you.

5.verse: All you think about is sex under those green trees where idols are worshiped. You sacrifice your children on altars built in valleys under rocky slopes.

6.verse: You have chosen to worship idols made of stone; you have given them offerings of wine and grain. Should I be pleased?

7.verse: You have spread out your beds on the tops of high mountains, where you sacrifice to idols.

8.verse: Even in your homes you have placed pagan symbols all around your huge beds. Yes, you have rejected me, sold yourselves to your lovers, and gone to bed with them.

9.verse: You smear on olive oil and all kinds of perfume to worship the god Molech. You even seek advice from spirits of the dead.

10.verse: Though you tired yourself out by running after idols, you refused to stop. Your desires were so strong that they kept you going.

11.verse: Did you forget about me and become unfaithful because you were more afraid of someone else? Have I been silent so long that you no longer fear me?

12.verse: You think you’re so good, but I’ll point out the truth.

13.verse: Ask your idols to save you when you are in trouble. Be careful though— it takes only a faint breath to blow them over. But if you come to me for protection, this land and my holy mountain will always belong to you.

14.verse: The LORD Helps the Helpless - The LORD says, “Clear the road! Get it ready for my people.”

15.verse: Our holy God lives forever in the highest heavens, and this is what he says: Though I live high above in the holy place, I am here to help those who are humble and depend only on me.

16.verse: My people, I won’t stay angry and keep on accusing you. After all, I am your Creator. I don’t want you to give up in complete despair.

17.verse: Your greed made me furious. That’s why I punished you and refused to be found, while you kept returning to your old sinful ways.

18.verse: I know what you are like! But I will heal you, lead you, and give you comfort, until those who are mourning

19.verse: start singing my praises. No matter where you are, I, the LORD, will heal you and give you peace.

20.verse: The wicked are a restless sea tossing up mud.

21.verse: But I, the LORD, have promised that none who are evil will live in peace.

1.verse: True Religion - Shout the message! Don’t hold back. Say to my people Israel: You’ve sinned! You’ve turned against the LORD.

2.verse: Day after day, you worship him and seem eager to learn his teachings. You act like a nation that wants to do right by obeying his laws. You ask him about justice, and say you enjoy worshiping the LORD.

3.verse: You wonder why the LORD pays no attention when you go without eating and act humble. But on those same days that you give up eating, you think only of yourselves and abuse your workers.

4.verse: You even get angry and ready to fight. No wonder God won’t listen to your prayers!

5.verse: Do you think the LORD wants you to give up eating and to act as humble as a bent-over bush? Or to dress in sackcloth and sit in ashes? Is this really what he wants on a day of worship?

6.verse: I’ll tell you what it really means to worship the LORD. Remove the chains of prisoners who are chained unjustly. Free those who are abused!

7.verse: Share your food with everyone who is hungry; share your home with the poor and homeless. Give clothes to those in need; don’t turn away your relatives.

8.verse: Then your light will shine like the dawning sun, and you will quickly be healed. Your honesty will protect you as you advance, and the glory of the LORD will defend you from behind.

9.verse: When you beg the LORD for help, he will answer, “Here I am!” Don’t mistreat others or falsely accuse them or say something cruel.

10.verse: Give your food to the hungry and care for the homeless. Then your light will shine in the dark; your darkest hour will be like the noonday sun.

11.verse: The LORD will always guide you and provide good things to eat when you are in the desert. He will make you healthy. You will be like a garden that has plenty of water or like a stream that never runs dry.

12.verse: You will rebuild those houses left in ruins for years; you will be known as a builder and repairer of city walls and streets.

13.verse: But first, you must start respecting the Sabbath as a joyful day of worship. You must stop doing and saying whatever you please on this special day.

14.verse: Then you will truly enjoy knowing the LORD. He will let you rule from the highest mountains and bless you with the land of your ancestor Jacob. The LORD has spoken!

1.verse: Social Injustice Is Condemned - The LORD hasn’t lost his powerful strength; he can still hear and answer prayers.

2.verse: Your sins are the roadblock between you and your God. That’s why he doesn’t answer your prayers or let you see his face.

3.verse: Your talk is filled with lies and plans for violence; every finger on your hands is covered with blood.

4.verse: You falsely accuse others and tell lies in court; sin and trouble are the names of your children.

5.verse: You eat the deadly eggs of poisonous snakes, and more snakes crawl out from the eggs left to hatch. You weave spider webs,

6.verse: but you can’t make clothes with those webs or hide behind them. You’re sinful and brutal.

7.verse: You hurry off to do wrong or murder innocent victims. All you think about is sin; you leave ruin and destruction wherever you go.

8.verse: You don’t know how to live in peace or to be fair with others. The roads you make are crooked; your followers cannot find peace.

9.verse: The People Confess Their Sins - No one has come to defend us or to bring about justice. We hoped for a day of sunshine, but all we found was a dark, gloomy night.

10.verse: We feel our way along, as if we were blind; we stumble at noon, as if it were night. We can see no better than someone dead.

11.verse: We growl like bears and mourn like doves. We hope for justice and victory, but they escape us.

12.verse: How often have we sinned and turned against you, the LORD God? Our sins condemn us! We have done wrong.

13.verse: We have rebelled and refused to follow you. Our hearts were deceitful, and so we lied; we planned to abuse others and turn our backs on you.

14.verse: Injustice is everywhere; justice seems far away. Truth is chased out of court; honesty is shoved aside.

15.verse: Everyone tells lies; those who turn from crime end up ruined. The LORD Will Rescue His People - When the LORD noticed that justice had disappeared, he became very displeased.

16.verse: It disgusted him even more to learn that no one would do a thing about it. So with his own powerful arm, he won victories for truth.

17.verse: Justice was the LORD’s armor; saving power was his helmet; anger and revenge were his clothes.

18.verse: Now the LORD will get furious and do to his enemies, both near and far, what they did to his people.

19.verse: He will attack like a flood in a mighty windstorm. Nations in the west and the east will then honor and praise his wonderful name.

20.verse: The LORD has promised to rescue the city of Zion and Jacob’s descendants who turn from sin.

21.verse: The LORD says: “My people, I promise to give you my Spirit and my message. These will be my gifts to you and your families forever. I, the LORD, have spoken.”

1.verse: A New Day for Jerusalem - Jerusalem, stand up! Shine! Your new day is dawning. The glory of the LORD shines brightly on you.

2.verse: The earth and its people are covered with darkness, but the glory of the LORD is shining upon you.

3.verse: Nations and kings will come to the light of your dawning day.

4.verse: Crowds Are Coming to Jerusalem - The LORD said: Open your eyes! Look around! Crowds are coming. Your sons are on their way from distant lands; your daughters are being carried like little children.

5.verse: When you see this, your faces will glow; your hearts will pound and swell with pride. Treasures from across the sea and the wealth of nations will be brought to you.

6.verse: Your country will be covered with caravans of young camels from Midian and Ephah. The people of Sheba will bring gold and spices in praise of me, the LORD.

7.verse: Every sheep of Kedar will come to you; rams from Nebaioth will be yours as well. I will accept them as offerings and bring honor to my temple.

8.verse: What is that sailing by like clouds or like doves flying home?

9.verse: On those distant islands your people are waiting for me, the LORD. Seagoing ships lead the way to bring them home with their silver and gold. I, the holy LORD God of Israel, do this to honor your people, so they will honor me.

10.verse: Jerusalem Will Be Rebuilt - The LORD said: Jerusalem, your city walls will be rebuilt by foreigners; their rulers will become your slaves. I punished you in my anger; now I will be kind and treat you with mercy.

11.verse: Your gates will be open day and night to let the rulers of nations lead their people to you with all their treasures.

12.verse: Any nation or kingdom that refuses to serve you will be wiped out.

13.verse: Wood from Lebanon’s best trees will be brought to you— the pines, the firs, and the cypress trees. It will be used in my temple to make beautiful the place where I rest my feet.

14.verse: The descendants of enemies who hated and mistreated you will kneel at your feet. They will say, “You are Zion, the city of the LORD, the holy God of Israel.”

15.verse: You were hated and deserted, rejected by everyone. But I will make you beautiful, a city to be proud of for all time to come.

16.verse: You will drain the wealth of kings and foreign nations. You will know that I, the mighty LORD God of Israel, have saved and rescued you.

17.verse: I will bring bronze and iron in place of wood and stone; in place of bronze and iron, I will bring gold and silver. I will appoint peace and justice as your rulers and leaders.

18.verse: Violence, destruction, and ruin will never again be heard of within your borders. “Victory” will be the name you give to your walls; “Praise” will be the name you give to your gates.
